114122112111332.content:
"HONEY, SHE'S GONE!" gasped Bill, turning around to face his beloved Tammy.

**

It had taken Willow Strasserman exactly twelve minutes and thirty-one seconds to fully calm down from her panic attack. She had had enough of them over the years to have a certain amount of self awareness of how she tends to react during these episodes, and given that she was now in a nice quiet room, literally her childhood bedroom, all alone, it helped the recovery process run a lot more smoothly than it otherwise could have. The woman out of time took a long, deep breath, and sighed. She felt her heart palpitations slowly fade away, and her heartbeat lower to her normal resting rate.

All better she whispered to herself quietly as the heat running across her cheeks evaporated.

Now that she had her head on straight again, the first thing that Willow wondered about was how painless teleportation had felt. She didn't know what she had been expecting when she had made that errant wish, but the experience of being spirited away had been completely mundane and uneventful. No feeling of being squished down through a narrow tube like the floo network in Harry Potter, or broken down to her constituent atoms and then reassembled like in Star Trek. One minute, she had been arguing with the teenage versions of her parents, and one wish later, here she was. It was like magic. It was magic.

"Looks like that gemstone took my wish to go home a bit literally" snarked the artsy blonde as she amazed herself at the familiarity of it all.

Here she was, sitting on the very same bed that she had slept in every night from when she was a toddler until she left for college, with even the same Gravity Falls themed blanket she had owned since she was six tucked into the mattress. Here she was, staring at the pink colored walls that had once upon a time been covered by posters of classic Disney and Studio Ghibli movies, and later on, darker & moodier stuff during her rebellious teenager phase. She smirked a bit, recalling the fight she had with her mother when Tammy saw the poster of the ultra offensive A Serbian Film laying above Willow's dresser one day, and how Tammy demanded in her *serious* voice to take it down, not happy with her normally sweet daughter watching such filth.

There were so many memories so had of this room. She remembered tea parties with her daddy and her stuffed animal collection. She remembered how she would jump out of the closet at random intervals to scare both of her parents who worried that she had been kidnapped. She remembered her first girlfriend Kylie, and their subsequent breakup. Willow had lost her virginity on this very bed.

Was any of that even real? She wasn't sure anymore. Slowly, she took a mental step back and went over the events of this morning.

When Willow had arrived home, her parents and Mrs. Vanapoulous were acting so weird! Like they weren't themselves. The three of them seemed completely shocked to see her there despite the fact that she had given them a week's notice that she was coming home for the weekend.

Her father hadn't been his normally confident, strapping alpha male self. He wasn't jovial or boisterous, and his posture seemed all wrong. The adult Bill Strasserman wasn't a macho man necessarily, but he had been very successful in life, and he had developed a bit of an ego over it. Willow recalled how a few of her childhood friends and even her third grade teacher had crushes on her ruggedly handsome father as he came to pick her up from school every day in his fancy sports car.

Earlier this morning though, her father seemed nervous. Timid. Geeky. His normally strong bear hug seemed weak and shaky and slightly effete. He stuttered just a little bit as he spoke, as if he had suddenly transformed from Superman to Clark Kent overnight.

And what about Mrs. Vanapoulous?

The middle aged friend of the family, who Willow had always thought was very beautiful, and had always been kind to Willow growing up, and was practically an honorary aunt, was not her usual fierce self either. This morning, she had seemed distant and cold, even slightly petulant. Willow had heard that she was going through a messy divorce, but that excuse seemed too easy, too simple for Willow's endlessly creative brain.

Finally, her mother. Willow knew that there was something wrong with her mom the second she entered the house. Nothing had been specifically wrong with Tammy on the surface, the curly topped young woman could just tell.

Willow and Tammy were extremely close with one another, as close as a mother and daughter could be, almost as if they had never completely cut the umbilical cord. She called her mom on the holophone every single day, and Willow felt comfortable telling her mother everything going on in her life, even the times where she was depressed or upset or wanting to tear her boss's head off for being an asshole. Tammy had done the same, sharing her own fears and regrets and the little delights happening to her throughout the day, or even just idle gossip from the neighborhood. The two women often sensed each other's thoughts and feelings, and Tammy joked that the two were psychically linked to each other.

This morning, Willow hadn't felt that. At all.

The Tammy Strasserman she had met had been an imposter. She was warm, and kind, but there was something in her eyes that suggested a lack of genuine maternal knowledge of Willow.

Later on, Willow had brought out the cool stuff, her concept art for the show she was creating, her big break into the industry she was so passionate about.

Normally, her parents would have gone gaga over it. Her father had never completely lost his geeky side. He was just as much into animation and comics as Willow was. The "real" Bill Strasserman and Willow could have gabbed about her show for hours. Her mother had a fangirl side to her too, and she was always interested in anything her daughter did.

Yet, neither had seemed all that excited by it. The parents she had witnessed in the living room were almost scared to see Willow's artwork for The Grellstone: Angry Transformations. They muttered among themselves like little squeaking mice, made some crappy little obvious lie to excuse themselves, and then quickly ran upstairs.

At first, Willow had been confused. Then she became hurt, believing that her parents didn't like her show idea, or maybe they were angry at her for some other reason, so she bolted upstairs to go check on them. She heard screaming coming from the guest bedroom. Then she saw an eerie green light coming through the cracks behind the door. She had covered her eyes with the crook of her elbow.

Then, when she lowered her elbow she had seen something much worse than the off chance Dad had snuck uranium into the house: the teenage versions of her mother and father and Gloria.

They were all so young! Her father was skinny as a rail, and he had acne scars running across his face! Her mother looked so much like she had at eighteen, except she was much shorter. Mrs Vanapoulous was positively stunning. Like, she was a Willow Strasserman perfect ten, someone that she'd want to go out with if the age difference didn't make it creepy.

Willow put two and two together once Dad explained what had happened with the stone(Which just by itself was incredibly creepy and meta, considering that it was the premise for her cartoon), and that's when she had her little existential crisis about whether or not she was real.

Willow took another big sigh.

"I guess it doesn't really matter anymore. With this stone, reality is whatever I say it is."

The young artist chuckled as held the pretty green gemstone in her hand, and turned it around a couple times, wondering what she should do with it.

If it behaved anything like the Grellstone from her cartoon, it was only possible to make a wish under extreme emotional duress. Anger. Hate. Fear. That sort of thing. It wasn't worth risking, especially by someone as sensitive as she was. Willow thought the best thing to do was find out where she was first and work from there. In all likelihood, if her bedroom was here, whatever parallel reality was currently stuck in couldn't be too different from the one she remembered coming from.

Or when she was, rather. Maybe she was actually in the correct timeline, but the stone had ferried her ten years too early to 2048! Then she'd open the door and bump into her dorky fifteen year old self getting ready for school! Willow chuckled at the idea of meeting her past self.

"Oh, who am I kidding myself? I'm still a dork. We'd probably get along."

Willow stood up and fatefully opened her bedroom door, her creative wheels turning.

"This might actually be a fun adventure!" Willow rationalized as she strolled casually down the familiar stairs and went inside the kitchen. Grabbing a can of Pepsi and a banana from the fridge, the girl had already noticed several subtle differences with the decoration of the home. First, the kitchen was wallpapered. The dinner table was also decorated differently, and the drapes blowing from the two open windows were yellow when she remembered them being off white.

Cracking open the soda can, Willow took a big, gluttonous gulp of the tasty carbonated beverage and then noticed a strange woman out of the corner of her eye standing in the foyer.

"Um..hi?" said Willow, giving an awkward little smile with her banana filled hand.

Who is this woman?

Option 1: Stephanie Donaldson, a witch who has been after the Ahn'Ger Stone for a long time, and has been keeping track of the mysterious gemstone's telltale "timequakes".

Option 2: Abby Reilly, a neighbor of the Strasserman's from the 2018 timeline, and noted religious fanatic. She believes Willow is her sinful lesbian daughter who's engaging in witchcraft!
114122112111332.title: Identity Crisis

114122112111333.content:
"I wish I were back home!" Willow shouted into the sky, the ominous green glow of the Ahn'Ger Stone erupting from her hand like a miniature star. In an blinding flash of light the wish was granted, and the small group opened their eyes to see the changes that had been wrought upon reality once more...

Option 1: The Ahn'Ger Stone, interpreting the mental patterns of Willow as well as the emotion behind the wish as well, turns Willow into an old lady that doesn't truly know where she is, is mostly blind and has a heart condition. Wanting to 'get back home', Old Lady Willow makes a harsh, mean wish when one of the teens tries to help her despite her protests.

Option 2: Unable to take her 'home', the Stone simply MAKES her home. Willow's body begins to merge with and change Bill's house!

1141221121113332.content:
Even without her father's exposition, it hadn't taken much for a creative girl like Willow to connect the dots.

Evidently magic emeralds are real, and so is time travel. My old babysitter made a wish hurtling everyone back to 2018, which is why my parents and Ms. Gloria are all baby faced teenagers again. The reason that everyone was acting so weird the minute I came home was because they were all fighting over the stone and who got to make a wish.

It all followed a certain kind of narrative logic, minus the new memories of herself being her father's sister and young enough to be in college again, which was just bizarre and off putting.

So this emerald can alter reality. That’s really, really scary. Who does it belong to though? I’ve never seen it in my mother’s jewelry box, and I doubt that it belongs to Ms. Gloria. Maybe one of them found it laying around somewhere? No...no, that’s too unrealistic.

As much as Willow tried to rationalize her irrational situation, the alarm bells inside her mind were klaxoning like mad. If her brain was controlled by tiny sentient emotions like in that old Pixar movie Inside Out, they were all running around screaming right now, Fear having already set himself on fire.

This was a full blown existential crisis. Paranoid musings like “Am I real?” and “Did I even exist before they made that wish?” crossed the curly haired young woman's psyche, alongside other worries far beyond her pay grade about the nature of reality, resulting in Willow to “Nope” herself into frenzied panic. The fact that her parents were cool with keeping secrets from her wasn’t helping her mental well being either, nor was how much Willow was secretly swooning at how fucking hot the younger Ms. Gloria was.

The enigmatic gemstone powered to life in the hand of the reluctant time traveler.

“Honey, please give that back to me or your father. You don’t know what that thing can do” Tammy pleaded feebly, her throat tightening from the stress.

“Well let’s find out, Mom! I wish I were home!” Willow screeched. The Ahn'Ger stone flared to life in her hand, creating a localized aurora right within the confines of the guest room. Across the street, a nosy neighbor momentarily thought they saw a blinding flash of unearthly green illumination coming from the second floor of the Strasserman residence, but dismissed it as being the effect of having done too much molly the night before and went on with their day.

When the uncanny luminescence finally subsided, the young trio saw the curious emerald drop to the floor with a clang. Willow was gone.

“Ohmigod!” shouted Bill and Tammy in unison.

“BILL, WHERE IS SHE?!”

“TAMMY, WHERE IS SHE?!”

Bill dashed for the gemstone laying on the floor. Snatching it up with his wide-cut hands, he made a wish.

“I WISH I KNEW WHERE WILLOW WAS!” he yelled, throttling the gemstone as if it were an uncooperative murder suspect in an interrogation room.

This time, the green-gold glare of the Ahn'Ger Stone was not all consuming, neither blinding nor dazzling Bill with its magical effigy, simply obeying his direct and uncomplicated demand. A beam of green shine launched itself directly into the teenager’s brain.

Tammy and Gloria watched in awe as Bill absorbed the answer to his question, his somewhat flushed face returning to its normal hue at first, and then all of a sudden heading in the opposite direction, turning white as a ghost. Tammy then watched curiously as her best friend turned husband turned boyfriend begin to quiver with fright, droplets of sweat erupting from his forehead.

“Bill, where is she?” demanded the petite blonde.

“She's here” Bill said fearfully, gulping strongly. “Willow's the house. The stone transformed Willow into the house.”

“What are you talking about? What do you mean she turned into the house?”

Bill took a deep breath.

“The stone” he said, lifting it up to show Tammy. “It can talk. It’s sentient, and it told me that when Willow wished that she was home, it took her wish literally. The house we're all standing in is alive. Willow is literally the house. She’s no longer a person.”

“What?!” yelled Tammy. “This isn’t some sick joke, is it? Where’s my baby?!”

“We’re standing on her.”

Tammy opened her mouth as if to say something like “That can’t be!”, but then shut it when she saw the grave look etched on her beloved’s face.

“Look honey, I can’t believe it either, but I swear that I’m telling the truth. The good news is, I think she can still communicate with us, if we try hard enough. Willow, can you hear me?!” yelled Bill to seemingly nobody in particular. “Sugarplum, don’t be scared! It’s your dad!”.

After a brief moment of doubt, Tammy joined Bill’s one man chorus and shouted as loudly as her 5’0 body could muster, giving in to the madness of the situation. She gently hugged the walls with her hands as if to console her child.

“Willow! Mommy’s here! Please let us know you’re OK!” she pleaded.

After about two minutes of the young couple’s fruitless search for their vanished daughter, a sound of cackling could be heard, causing Bill and Tammy to whip around like cats.

“Are you fucking serious?” Gloria asked incredulously, struggling to hold back her overflowing stream of mean-spirited laughter. “You two mental patients really believe that Willow's the house?”

“Yes” said Bill sharply, turning around to face Gloria. Tammy’s pleasant looking face began to boil over with rage.

“This house, right here? The one we’re all standing in, it’s alive? Like, alive alive?” Gloria asked aggressively like some investigative journalist.

“Yes, alive alive.”

“How is she even breathing without lungs?”

“I don’t know if Willow even needs to breath right now. This thing is magic, it’s definitely doesn’t obey any natural laws” answered Bill, looking down slightly disturbed by the emerald he held tightly in his grip.

“Oh great, magic. The answer to everything.”

“Why are you being skeptical of all people?!” admonished Tammy. “You were just with us in the future ten minutes ago!”

“It’s called critical thinking, duh!” replied Gloria. “Traveling through time and transforming into inanimate objects are like two completely different categories. Just because you’re head over heels with Bill doesn’t mean that I have to be too, Tom!”

“It’s Tammy!”

“Whatever, shorty” Gloria answered dismissively, turning back to Bill. “So can Willow like, see? You know, without eyes? Ohmigod, please don’t tell me the house has a pair of eyes.”

“Um, I don’t know. The gemstone didn’t tell me that.”

“Well, what did it tell you? I want specifics!”

Bill made a frustrated noise that sounded like a kazoo.

The geeky side of him was thinking back to the old Mystery Science Theater 3000 theme song: “If you're wondering how he eats and breaths, and other science facts, then repeat to yourself 'It’s just a show, I should really just relax!'”. He wanted to repeat it to Gloria, but he knew that she wouldn’t get it.

“It...it told me that that Willow was really upset about us not telling her about the gemstone. She, um, she felt a little bit betrayed.”

From the corner of his eye, Bill saw Tammy’s look of hurt. He knew how much being a good mother meant to her.

“Oh my god! Your daughter decided to yeet herself out of this decade rather than hang around with the likes of you two, and now she’s turned into brick and mortar! You guys are the worst parents ever.”

Gloria covered her mouth, having failed to hold back her fit of giggles.

“All of this is your fault!” growled Bill. “If you hadn’t shown up here uninvited and made that stupid wish of yours, we wouldn’t even have a daughter to be worried about, and now you have you have the gall the laugh at us? I always knew that you were a bitch, but...”

“Bitch?! Fuck you, nerd. Nobody gets to use the b-word on me, and especially not you!”

“GLORIA, THIS ISN'T THE TIME!” shrieked Tammy.

“Shut up, Tom, nobody asked you anything! God, you're so self centered. Hey, maybe you really are better suited to be a chick, because you sure do whine as much as one! And Bill, you should be grateful that I gave you a girlfriend. It’s not like you were ever going to find one yourself!”

“SHUT UP!”

“Unless you count Big Jon or Rob, both of whom I’m sure would love to buttfuck you like you’re the new guy in prison. I mean, they have to be gay to be so obsessed with tormenting you all the livelong day, right? But then again, that would make you their girlfriend since you’d be the bitch in that situation. The point is, you’re a loser, Bill, and you would have never found someone to even have a daughter with in the first place if it weren’t for me. Be grateful is all I’m saying.”

“SHUT. UP.” demanded Bill through gritted teeth. The gemstone in his hands flared to life.
1141221121113332.title: Life As A House, Part 1

11412211211133321.content:
“Help us find Willow, or get the hell out of here!” shouted Tammy, pointing forcefully towards the door, her eyes burning with hatred.

“Guys, did you forget how I saved all three of our asses from that awful future we were just in? You two should be hoisting me on your shoulders!”

“GET OUT!” screamed Bill as loudly as he had ever screamed before. In the back of his mind, he was so glad that his parents weren’t home to hear all of this fighting.

Gloria paused at the furious couple, in genuine shock at how angry they were with her, unused to anyone challenging her authority. A moment of tense silence went by as she thought about what to say next.

“Look Bill, I’m sorry, OK? It’s been a hell of a morning, and when I get stressed out, I tend to have a serpent’s tongue. Just ask Tom. I was only screwing with you guys when I was laughing about Willow turning into a house. I..I guess I wasn’t 100% sure if you were serious.”

The hardy expression of Bill’s face softened just a little bit.

“I am serious. As serious as you can get. But to be fair to you as much as I hate doing that, I know how crazy this all sounds. If you really are sorry, I guess can meet you halfway. As you can see, tensions are really high between Tammy and I right now, so you just get out of here, I’ll be willing to let bygones be bygones.”

“It’s a deal.”

“Good. Now if you’d be kind enough to not step too hard on the staircase when you’d leave, I’d really appreciate it. Because I think that’s Willow’s spine.”

Gloria gave a polite laugh.

“You’re so funny, I wasn’t expecting that! You know Bill, I wasn’t lying earlier when I said that I liked you. You’re a sweet guy, and Tom...Tammy is lucky to have you” Gloria said, rolling her eyes a little at Tom’s magical sex change. “Friends?”

Bill’s eye trailed down towards Tammy, as if to ask her if this was a trick or not. The petite girl’s expression had remained hateful and intense.

“Help us find Willow, and I’ll think about forgiving you” Tammy replied icily.

“Um, babe, I think Gloria just wants to go to school. Let’s let her mosey on out of here, so we can….”

“No! You said it yourself, Bill. Gloria started this, so she can finish it. If she’s really sorry, she can start by making up for the lifetime of bullshit she’s put us through.”

“Excuse me?” said Gloria, rising to her full height, crossing her arms under her breasts. She noticed for the first time how much she now towered over her former boyfriend. For what it was worth, Tammy didn’t flinch at all.

“I won’t even get in to all of the awful things you’ve done to me over the years, or to how many other poor souls that ever had the misfortune of meeting you. Let’s just focus on this morning, mmmkay? First you show up at Bill’s house uninvited when you knew that he’d be alone so it’d easier to rope him into one of your little schemes. Then the moment I show up to escort him to school so he doesn’t get harassed by Big Jon, you start a pointless argument with the both of us because you’re not being paid attention to. Then, you childishly steal what rightfully belonged to him, and made some thoughtless wish with it, which is what led to all of this happening.”

“What are you trying to say?”

“I’m saying that a leopard can’t change its spots, and a true bitch like you can’t help but show her bitchy true colors. I’ve been down this road before, Bill, don’t ever believe a word that this snake in the grass says. She’s not sorry about anything. And for the record, Gloria, I am never going back with you. Fuck you.”

“You know what? Fuck you both, and fuck future girl!” whined Gloria as she began stamping hard on the floor of the Strasserman guest bedroom like a child, her face turning rabid. “Can Willow feel me pounding on the fucking floor, Tom?! Huh? Huh?!”

OWW!

Without warning, the Strasserman home began to very visibly sway side to side, knocking the three teens to the floor. Gloria made an “oof” sound as she fell onto her butt.

Downstairs, Bill heard his mother’s china falling out of the cabinets and something that he was pretty sure was the expensive 4k television collapse upon the living room floor.

“Shit” he whispered as he wiped some sweat from his brow.

He gazed down at Tammy, who he smiled at for finally standing up to her ex. Tammy smiled back. They held hands.

“Ohmigod, are we having an earthquake?!” shouted Gloria as the house continued to tremble.

Tammy moaned.

“Didn’t you you listen to a word I said, you bimbo?!” yelled Bill.

“Hey, I said no b-words!”

“OK, I’ll call you a retard! Or a fucking idiot! You’d have to be deaf to not hear what I said! Our daughter has turned into the house, and you just made her very mad!”

MOM? DAD? boomed a disembodied voice.

“Honey?!” exclaimed Bill and Tammy in unison.

Holy shit, he was telling the truth whispered Gloria.

MOM AND DAD, PLEASE STOP YELLING AT MS. GLORIA! I DON’T KNOW WHY SHE’S ACTING THIS WAY, BUT SHE’S A GREAT PERSON!

...OR AT LEAST SHE BECOMES GREAT WHEN SHE’S OLDER! SHE’S MY FRIEND AND I WON’T STAND EITHER OF YOU BEING SO MEAN TO HER! SO KNOCK IT OFF!

Just to prove that she meant business, the Strasserman home began swaying side to side again, forcing the teenage trio inside to remain planted to the floor. Down the street, a rather perceptive dog starting barking loudly at what it perceived as an unnatural occurrence.

“OK!” Bill yelled in a firm but clear voice, as if he were a hostage negotiator. “We got it! We promise not to yell at Gloria anymore! But Willow, please, we need to know what you’re going through right now! I asked the magic emerald what happened to you, and it told me that it transmuted you into the house! Is that true?!”

YES! I’M REALLY SCARED, DAD! I...I CAN’T EVEN DESCRIBE WHAT I AM ANYMORE OR WHERE I AM! THIS IS FREAKIER THAN WHEN I DID ACID IN COLLEGE!

“You did what?!” squealed Tammy angrily. “Young lady, I…”

Bill shushed her.

“Can you see us right now?!”

NO, I CAN’T SEE ANYTHING! I CAN’T SEE, SMELL, HEAR, TASTE, OR TOUCH. IT’S LIKE I DON’T EVEN EXIST!

“Or it’s like you’re Helen Keller” Gloria added bitterly.

“Then how are you talking to us right now?!” asked Bill, ignoring the desire to strangle Gloria.

IT’S WEIRD.

“We know all about weird, baby, just tell us!”

I HAVE A...IT’S LIKE A SIXTH SENSE! I CAN’T SEE ANYTHING, BUT I CAN **FEEL** EVERYTHING THAT’S INSIDE AND AROUND THE HOUSE! IT’S LIKE EVERYTHING IS A PART OF ME! I CAN FEEL YOU AND MOM AND MS. GLORIA SITTING INSIDE THE GUESTROOM FLOOR. I CAN FEEL EVERY BIT OF FOOD INSIDE THE REFRIGERATOR IN THE KITCHEN, EVERY SINGLE UTENSIL THAT’S INSIDE THE DRAWER. I CAN FEEL EVERY WALL, EVERY FLOOR, EVERY CEILING, ALL OF THE CLOTHES AND THE STACKS OF OLD GAMES IN YOUR BEDROOM CLOSET! I CAN EVEN FEEL ALL OF THE ANTS AND MILLIPEDES CRAWLING UNDER THE FRONT LAWN! EWW, THEY’RE SO GROSS!

“Can you sense anything beyond our house?!” Bill asked.

NO! IT’S LIKE BEING STUCK IN SOLITARY CONFINEMENT, AND I HATE IT! I CAN EXPERIENCE EVERY NOOK AND CRANNY OF THE HOUSE AT ONCE, BUT I CAN’T SEE ANYTHING BEYOND THE MAILBOX! I CAN FEEL THE RAIN FALLING ON ME THOUGH! I REALLY FUCKED UP MY WISH. I’M SORRY DAD.

“It’s...it’s OK honey, we’re going to get you out of this!” yelled Bill as he grabbed Tammy’s shoulder supportively.

BY THE WAY, YOU GUYS KNOW THAT ROB BOLSTRUM IS LURKING AROUND THE BASEMENT, RIGHT?
11412211211133321.title: Life As A House, Part 2

114122112112.content:
Bill, Gloria, and Tammy all traded knowing glances with one another, and somehow, they all knew that they were thinking the same thing. It worked! Gloria's wish worked! Well, sure, it wasn't 100% effective since Tom was still a girl and Willow was still around, but hey, close enough right?. They can figure the hard stuff later. Tammy was secretly the most excited out of all of them, as she was now free of the horrible burden of being Tom, and she wanted to see what her life held in front of her now that she had a fresh start.

“So Willow” asked Bill turning to the fourth person in the room, trying to break the ice. He hesitated, not knowing what to say to his future daughter. He didn't know how accepting she would be at such a bizarre situation. Was she in shock? It was hard to say. Bill was afraid that she wouldn't take it well, so he decided not to push the question directly. “Are you OK, sweetie?”

Willow gave Bill a funny look, furrowing her eyebrows like he had just farted in her direction.

“Of course I'm fine, little bro! I just asked you if you wanted a ride to school.”

The color in Bill's skin suddenly evaporated.

“S-sure.”

“Well alright then! I'll drop you all off on the way. Come on, guys!” said Willow. She was practically skipping out of the room, seemingly expecting the trio of friends to follow her lead. Slowly, they all started walking. Gloria, Tammy, and Bill started whispering to each other.

“What's going on here?” asked Gloria.

As Bill passed by a framed photo of the Strasserman family that was affixed onto the wall next to the stairwell, something odd caught his eye.

“Hold on a minute” he said, walking past Tammy and Gloria. He walked back upstairs two stairs at a time and looked back at the photo.

“Holy shit. Guys! Come here, quick!”

“What now?” whined Gloria, still holding to the stone as she turned around and ascended the staircase. Tammy did the same. She was mostly quiet, but wasn't liking where this was going.

“What is it?” asked Tammy.

“Look” pointed Bill.

The family photo showed Bill, Willow, and two adults who looked almost like his parents. Almost, but not quite. The differences were subtle, but just detectable enough to unsettle Bill into realizing that something was off. The uncanny valley.

“Oh my god” said Tammy, immediately understanding Bill's meaning.

“What? What's wrong?” asked Gloria. She had never met Bill's mother and father, as Bill was normally an acquaintance to her at best, the two teens only knowing each other through Tom.

“My mom and dad. This isn't them. I remember taking this photo two years ago, and this isn't them. These are impostors. And my little sister Kimberly is missing in the photo.”

“We're still not in the right reality” said Tammy blankly, now much less enthusiastic about her life.

“Shit!” said Gloria. “I thought I did it right this time!”

She banged her fist against the wall in frustration.

“It's not your fault, Gloria, but this is dead serious. Who the hell are these people?” asked Bill.

“Bill! Gloria! Tammy! You coming?” asked Willow from the front door. Her car was parked in front of the house and was ready to go.

Option 1: In the new reality, Willow is Bill's older sister by a couple of years. She is currently attending college and she drives her brother and friends to school. There, they realize that everything is slightly off there as well.

Option 2: In the heat of the moment, the Stone is used to make a wish.

Option 3: Something else happens.
114122112112.title: The Uncanny Valley

choices: Bill, Tammy and Gloria notice more subtle but otherwise normal changes at school
Bill, Tammy and Gloria head straight for class. At other ends of the building.
1141221121121.content:
“Bill! Gloria! Tammy! You coming?” Willow's voice called out from the front door. Bill ignored his future daughter-turned older sister's voice as he attempted to console Gloria, but the longer he stood staring at the picture of his changed family, the angrier he became. He was just about to explode when he felt two soft hands on his shoulder and arm. Bill's head snapped to the left and the anger he felt faded away as he saw Tammy's concerned face.

"Hey...We can figure it out at school, okay?" Tammy's voice was soft and calm as she stroked Bill's broad shoulders and gave his arm a supportive squeeze.

Bill felt the anger fading away as the touch of his best friend-turned wife-turned...something brought back Bill's level-headedness. They did have all day to figure out how to control the gemstone and get everything back to normal. Right now they just needed to get to school before anything else happened.

"Yeah. Yeah, we can." Bill said with a nod, and the three teenagers soon piled into Willow's economy car and were off to school. As Bill stared out the passenger side window, listening to Willow talk to the girls in the backseat about...something pointless, he considered it at least something of a small miracle that reality had ended up this way. Two blocks later, a small thunderstorm had interrupted the pleasant morning weather, heavy raindrops pouring down on anyone caught on the street, including Jon Ingerman and Rob Bolstrum. The bullies of the high school, both with a grudge against BIll that apparently persisted in this new reality, the two ogre-like teens had clearly been waiting for Bill on his usual path to school before being dislodged by the surprise rain. Despite the similar downpour of thoughts running through his mind at the moment, Bill couldn't help but grin at the sight of the two bullies getting soaked as they dashed for cover.

But then Bill blinked as Willow pulled to a stop at the intersection. Instead of the two bullies there was now just Big Jon and a...girl? The two of them were hunkered under the short awning of an apartment building, BIg Jon's letterman jacket covered arms craned almost protectively over a red haired girl dressed to the nines in full punk clothing, leather jacket, bare mid-riff, torn apart jeans and boots, a cigarette clinging to life in her fingers. She looked almost like a...female version of Rob? What was going on? The two shared a quick kiss as Bill blinked in confusion and worry before Willow's car accelerated forward.

Meanwhile, in the backseat, Tammy was going through a similar cascade of thoughts and emotions. She loved this body, she felt happy, happier than she could ever remember being as Tom. But that happiness was tempered by worry over the stone, which was still in Gloria's possession, worry that Bill, her darling Bill, didn't want her to remain Tammy, and remorse over the fact that Willow, her baby, was no longer her baby. At this point there was very little Tom left within Tammy's mind. She could still remember being him, but she also remembered two entire lifetimes of being Tammy. The greater sum of memories being her older self; a wife and mother and an entire life lived, while now she also had full memories of this life. Of being Tammy the teenager, being Bill's best friend and sharing a deep, almost soul-mate like bond with despite the two of them never acting on it.

Both of these realities were preferable to what Tammy had been and if nothing else, she had to figure out a way to get the stone so she could make everyone forget she was ever Tom. She could live with this reality, but no matter what, she had to erase Tom Ackerton from whatever level of existence he still remained on. No matter what.

And for Gloria, well, Gloria was the target of a intensive, gossipy interrogation by Willow, whom she was still incredibly weirded out by. From the few minutes of small talk that kept her thoughts from drifting towards more paranormal matters. Apparently Willow looked up to Gloria's mother, which gave the younger Vanapolous chills. Willow was still persuing an artistic career in this reality and Ariadne, Gloria's mother, had apparently been something of an short-lived splash in the art world before motherhood had sent her down another path. Willow was a big fan of Ariadne's art and was clearly smoozing for a meet and greet, while Gloria had no real idea what the newly created woman was talking about. To her knowledge, her mother had never shown any inclination towards creativity, instead just that constant sneer of cold command and logic, the need for more power and control. But as strange as it might have been, it could have also possibly been true; Gloria knew very little about her mother's past.

And during the final silence as the high school loomed in the distance, Willow decided to drop a bombshell.

"So Gloria, are you still seeing Matt Harris?"

Gloria blinked in confusion, "Matt Harris?"

"You know, pride of the school, captain of like all the ball teams? Oh no, are you two fighting?"

"Uh...." Gloria's thought process scattered into static as it struggled to process the information. The only Matt Harris that she knew had been that loser Sophmore, a greasy little pervert with anger issues that she would occasionally pick on, whenever she hadn't been blasting Tom or some poor girl that earned her wrath. And he definitely wasn't captain of any of the ball teams! She'd NEVER date such a little turd! Out of instinct she cast a sidelong look at Tom...But only saw Tammy, who was staring at her blankly, seemingly unconcerned about Gloria's dating life. Any mention of 'another man' in Tom's presence had been enough to drive him into a rage but this...girl that she had turned him into appeared to give zero fucks. And she looked so comfortable in her geeky, slightly chubby but still cute form. Like she'd always been that way. Was Tom in there at all? Gloria could feel the edges of the gemstone cutting into her palm as real fear set in.

She wasn't sure if she had loved Tom, but something about how naturally at ease that Tammy looked made part of her heart break.

"Gloria?" Willow asked from the driver seat, but her timing was poor. They had just pulled into the drop-off lane of the high school, and the three teens were quick to leap out and race through the rain to the school doors. Willow just stared at her younger brother and shrugged.

"Man, what is up with them today?" She said to herself as she slowly accelerated away from the high school and off towards the local community college.

11412211211222.content:
Bill had been rather calm and collected throughout this entire ordeal, taking the insane changes to reality like a pro, rolling with them and being the only one among the three restored teenagers to keep a level head. But even as he told Gloria that the changes were not her fault, he could feel something hot and primal forming in his gut as he stared at the picture of his changed family. It was true the differences were subtle but there was no mistaking that Bill's mom and dad were different people. His 'dad' with different colored hair, glasses, eyes the wrong color. His 'mom' who was taller than she should have been, heavier, a more modern sense of fashion, higher cheekbones.

And then there was Kimberley's absence. Bill wandered down the hallway, his eyes roaming across the various pictures that were hanging there showing various scenes of his new parents, of Willow, of himself, of strangers that were now his grandparents. But not a single picture of Kimberly. Bill raced to the door that had led to Kimberley's bedroom, tossing it open to reveal the room of a young adult woman, tidy, modern, not at all like the almost unbearably girly room that had belonged to Kimberley. His little sister had been wiped from existence entirely. He felt numb as he stood in the doorway, staring at what was clearly Willow's room, not hearing Tammy and Gloria approaching from behind or the repeated calls from his new older sister. There was just the sound of his heart pounding in his ears until Gloria's voice sliced through the shock like a piece of glass on a chalkboard.

"This is all your fault, Tom! If you had just apologized for being an ass like you were supposed to then none of this would have happened!"

The fury that had been building in his stomach surged upwards, and Bill roared in anger, spinning around on his heel as his face contorted with rage. Gloria screamed as Tammy jumped backwards, her eyes wide.

"THIS. IS. ALL. YOUR. FAULT. YOU. STUPID. BITCH!" Bill roared into Gloria's face as he loomed over her. The formerly dominant girl seemed to shrink as she stumbled backwards into the wall.

"N-no, this, this is Tom's fau-AAHHH!" She attempted to say but was silenced once more as Bill's hand lashed out and backhanded Gloria across her pretty face. The teenage diva screamed in pain and brought both of her hands up to protect her face from any other blows.

And in her pained fear, Gloria opened her hands and the gemstone that had caused everything to go wrong in the span of just a few short minutes went flying through the air, clacking against the hallway windows and tumbling to the hard wooden floor. And Bill, in his rage, shoved Gloria up against the wall once more as his eyes locked on the stone, pushing his best friend's ex against the wall as he raced towards it, picking in up in one aggressive swipe. Green-gold light immediately began shining through the cracks in Bill's fingers as he spun around and shook his now enclosed, glowing fist at the two girls.

"I wish..."
11412211211222.title: Raging Bill

114122112112221.content:
"I wish that my true parents were here, right now!"

With Bill's wish, several things could happen.

1. The Ahn'Ger Stone morphs Gloria and Tammy into Bill's parents, Gloria becoming his dad while Tammy becomes his mother. Bill and WIllow both change to match their parent's new appearances, but do their memories change as well?

2. Bill's original mom and dad materialize in the house, having no idea how they got there or who any of these kids are. Chaos and heartbreak ensue as Bill attempts to convince them that they really are his mom and dad.

3. Bill's new mom and dad suddenly appear, both very confused as to why they were no longer at work, angering Bill even further.
114122112112221.title: Parental Choices (Options)

1141221121122211.content:
“I wish that my true parents were here, right now!” screamed Bill with righteous fury in his voice, almost foaming at the mouth like a rabid dog. He on the verge of sobbing, lost and unable to think straight due to a toxic combination of ire, anxiety, and grief over the perceived loss of his family. If he could see himself, he would be aghast at the mess he now was.

To add to this maelstrom, twinges of guilt already began to manifest. Bill was normally not a violent person, and despite feeling that she deserved it, he saw the look of fear in Gloria's eyes as he loomed over her. He was about to apologize to Gloria for hitting her before he noticed that it wasn't exactly his beet red face she was staring at with rapt concern. Instead, she was staring at his glowing fist. His eyes trailed downward...

Bill opened his palm, revealing the damaged Ahn'Ger Stone and the effect that it was generating. Despite the crack running through it, the stone was currently shining brighter than it had the first two times it had been used. To Bill, it was as if he was holding a miniature star in the palm of his hand. He stared at the stone in genuine awe, astonished at its power.

Time seemed to be slowing down to the teenage boy, as if every second were an hour and every minute a day, but despite this feeling, or perhaps because of it, the magic of the stone struck again. He watched as time and space warped around him like he was on the world's worst acid trip. The domicile that Bill, Tammy, and Gloria were standing in began to melt into a riot of colors and configurations. Before reality finally reset itself once more, the last thing that Bill heard was his name being called out by Tammy's haunted voice. She feared losing him, and Bill feared losing her, but the latter could not dwell on lost on. Bill instead wondered what insane life he was heading to next.

**

“Bill! Bill!”

The ringing of Bill's name suddenly caught his attention. He looked around, and found himself back in his bedroom. After breathing a deep sigh of relief, now somewhat used to the nature of shifting locations, the teenage boy quickly inspected for anything that was out of place, and by anything, Bill meant anything. To his relief, Bill found that nothing in his room seemed to be altered or bizarrely out of place. His baseball cards, his comics and video games were still all organized to his specification, and the clothing in his dresser were still all the same. His telescope was still present. Even the white walls were the same.

He quickly looked down at himself. He was still dressed in the same clothing and shoes.

He patted himself down. Nope, no tail. No forked tongue. No breasts or any signs that his body had been altered in any way. Not even the color of his shirt was different.

“Woohoo, I'm normal!” he muttered to himself in an attempt to keep his sanity.

Most importantly, the Ahn'Ger Stone remained in his hand, back to its dormant state, though unfortunately still damaged.

“Bill! Champ, we need you! Please come downstairs!” shouted the same voice again. Bill didn't recognize it, which deflated his already shaky confidence that reality had indeed returned to normal in its entirety. Cautiously, Bill didn't answer back, not knowing who this person was. Slowly, he walked out into the hallway, back to the family photo that had set him off.

It wasn't there.

The location of the family photo wasn't there. Not even the one with his fake parents.

He continued to take stock of the house. Other than the missing portrait, everything else looked normal.

Anxiety concerning his family's whereabouts began to resurface in Bill's mind once more. He was about to inspect Kimberly's room to see if it had returned to its relentless assault of pink, but he was interrupted in this pursuit.

“Bill! What are you staring at? C'mon honey, or we'll be late!”

The teenager was shaken out of his state by yet another voice at the bottom of the stairs.

“C'mon, pumpkin. We're all packed and ready to go! We're just waiting for you, and we can't leave until our darling Bill is ready. .”

He turned his head and discovered perhaps the last person that he had expected to see again.

It was Tammy! Not the Tammy he just left...it was the grown up Tammy. The middle aged one that he's married to in 2058! She was dressed casually in cut off jean shorts and a white top, a pair of dark sunglasses tucked into her collar. If Bill could guess, she looked like she was ready to go on vacation or a trip to the beach. But it was still April...

Walking down the stairs in a daze, he approached the older blonde woman once known as Tom Ackerton with confused emotion and disappointment that nope, things were not entirely back to normal after all. Once he reached the last step, Tammy immediately rubbed Bill's hair, though the gesture felt more playful than romantic.

“God, I'm going to miss you when you leave for college” she said, hugging him with a tight, affectionate squeeze.

“Tammy?” he asked with confusion as she held him tightly.

“Getting too old to call me Mom?” as she let him go to look deeply into his eyes.

“Mom?” asked Bill in surprise.

As Bill looked into the eyes of his best friend slash future wife slash girlfriend, he definitely noticed that hopelessly devoted look was gone. Instead, it was replaced by something else. Still affectionate, still loving, but different. He wanted to say that it was the look his real mom gave him, but he didn't want to go down that road.

“Tammy!? Where is that kid? I'm not waiting another second!” once again shouted the mysterious voice.

A dark haired man entered the foyer, dressed in a black t-shirt and tan pants. He looked rather handsome, reminding Bill a bit of John Stamos, but the teenager had never seen this man before in his life. The man began to speak with an annoyed countenance.

“Bill, what are you doing? You want to go on vacation or do you want to spend all summer stuck in your room?” he asked with an exasperated tone to the teenager who was slowly realizing what was going on.

“Hold your horses, Gene, for Pete's Sake!” said Tammy with a hint of annoyance before grabbing her son's hand. The man exited through the front door dramatically before Bill looked into Tammy's face again.

“C'mon Bill, summer awaits!” smiled Tammy, pulling him forward towards the front door as they followed the man named Gene. They piled onto the front porch.

As Tammy locked the front door, Bill saw the family station wagon packed with luggage, and a couple of of passengers waiting in the back. The weather was stiflingly hot, the front lawn was vibrantly green, as were the row of trees lining the opposite street.

Reluctantly, Bill followed the smiling woman down the front porch. As she locked it, Bill checked his watch.

“July 25th, 2018. 8:45 A.M.”

He had just jumped forward three months in time. Tammy was apparently his mother now, and a complete stranger was his father...unless...no. No! That black haired man couldn't possibly be Gloria, could it? It was the only semi-reasonable answer the teenager could grab onto. The stone clearly wasn't afraid to alter people's gender.

Reluctantly, he entered the backseat, still holding tightly onto the broken artifact that he thrust his life in three bizarre new directions over the course of one morning. He turned to look at his fellow passengers.


Option 1: It was Kimberly and Willow! The Ahn'Ger Stone brought back his little sister into the mix without sacrificing his former daughter Willow, still his older sister. However, both siblings look subtly yet noticeably different due to different parentage, confirming Bill's suspicions that Gloria is his new father. When Bill sees his own altered appearance in the window reflection, he makes another angry wish.

Option 2: It was his real parents! Well...his real parents as they were as teenagers, anyway. With his older sister Willow off on her own summer sojourn with her college friends, Bill's new parents asked if he wanted his two best friends Greg Strasserman and Martha Hanson to tag along with him on a Vanapoulos family vacation.
1141221121122211.title: The Grand Reshuffle

11412211211222112.content:
“C'mon Bill, summer awaits!” smiled Tammy, pulling him forward towards the front door as they followed the man named Gene. They piled onto the front porch. As he felt this version of Tammy's soft but firm grip, Bill still couldn't believe it, the Stone had, for some reason, twisted his entire wish and had transformed his Tammy into his new mother! And if his quickly forming hunch was correct, that meant that Gene had to be Gloria and was now his father!.

The wall of oppressive summer heat hit him like a ton of bricks and immediately a thin layer of sweat began forming on his brow. Summers in the American Midwest were always hot, but it seemed especially so in the weird time jump that had occurred with the wish. Not to mention the oppressive brightness of the morning sun as it lit the world beyond the protective covering of the porch.

"Christ, we should have gotten going earlier like I wanted. Its gonna be some hard driving with the sun in my eyes all day" Gene said, and Bill saw the dark haired man that was apparently now his father cast an annoyed look at both him and Tammy.

"Gene, I was not going to make everyone get up at the crack of dawn just because you do. We're on vacation! We can afford to relax a little!" Tammy's voice had an edge to it as she rolled her eyes at her husband.

"That's about the only thing we'll be able to afford after this. Taking a big vacation when we've got a kid in college and another one a month away? Bleeding me dry over here, honey" Gene pulled one of his pants pockets inside out in dramatic fashion, to which Tammy just crossed her slightly flabby arms.

"Oh just get in the car, Gene!" The former man turned Bill's wife turned geeky teenage girlfriend turned Bill's mom said with a dismissive wave. Gene turned and took a few steps towards the small set of stairs leading down off the porch before he stopped.

"Don't forget to lock the door like you did last time!" Gene warned, "I swear if mom calls and says the door is hanging wide open again, we're coming straight home and never taking another vacation!"

"That's what I'm doing right. Now. Honey." Tammy hissed as she dug into her purse, pulling out a loaded key chain.

"Well good. I locked the other ones while we were waiting on Bill, so get it locked so we can get our asses in gear!" Gene turned and stomped his way down the steps and across the small pathway that curved towards the rumbling station wagon.

'That's new' Bill thought to himself, having been frozen in the awkwardly tense exchange between his best friend turned mom and his best friend's ex-turned dad. Before, in the old reality there was just the concrete path that led to the sidewalk, but in this new reality one of his new 'parents' must have decided that walking three feet across grass was unacceptable and had made a secondary path to the driveway. In the gap between the new path and the house there was now a small garden of roses and other flowers that, in the baking heat of summer, looked like they could use a drink.

As his gaze followed Gene to the car, Bill could see two other bodies in the back seat of the station wagon, though with the glare from the morning light he couldn't tell who they were, but he figured he'd find out soon enough.

"Ugh, I love that man, but sometimes I just want to strangle him!" Tammy muttered to herself as she turned towards the front door, pulling out a particular key and sliding it into the two locks. The short blonde dropped the keys back into her purse with a sigh and turned to face Bill, given him a strained smile.

"Don't worry about that, sweetheart. You know how your dad gets when he's under pressure. C'mon, let's get this show on the road! Two weeks of fun in the sun!" Bill's new mom chuckled at her own little rhyme as a more genuine smile grew on her face. as she hooked grabbed Bill's arm and practically dragged him to the station wagon.

As they approached the waiting automobile Bill shot a look at the luggage area, seeing a pile of suitcases, recognizing his but the rest were unknown to him, one of them a bright pink that sat on top of a dull, old looking Chicago Cubs themed suitcase that triggered something within Bill's memory, but he couldn't figure out what. But before he could ask a question, Tammy was opening the backseat passenger door for him and a wave of cool air washed over him. Reluctantly, he entered the backseat, still holding tightly onto the broken artifact that he thrust his life in three bizarre new directions over the course of one morning. He turned to look at his fellow passengers, and his heart suddenly jumped into his throat.

There, sitting practically on top of him, were the teenage versions of his original mom and dad! Martha was sitting in the middle, her brown hair in long and slightly curly as it was draped over her bare shoulders. Her face was youthful and full of life, and every bit as pretty as Bill remembered it being even without the 90s style make-up from old family pictures. Her lips were parted in a warm smile as they said something, but Bill couldn't tell what as the sound of his pulse thundered away in his ears. He found his eyes drifting downward in disbelief, following the straps of his former mother's tank top and bra down to two modest breasts, to the barely visible mid-rift and the cut-off jean shorts she was wearing, all the way down to the sandals that sat between her toes.

And then Bill's shocked gaze turned to the other occupant in the back seat, sitting on the other side of the car. It was his dad, Greg! It took Bill a few seconds to connect the dots on who the other young man had been, his father's signature 'Henry Cavill 'stache'' no longer resting proudly on his upper lip. Instead the younger version of his former dad was wearing a Chicago Cubs ball cap and clean shaven, an almost baby-faced look with eyes that clearly didn't need glasses. Yet. And even though he knew the old version of his dad wore the Cubs hat on vacation because of the bald spot, the tufts of hair in slight need of a rm stuck out from under the rim of the hat.

As Mom-Tammy opened the passenger side door and slid into her seat, the world leap back to normal speed and the pounding in his ears fade away.

"Bill, are you okay?" His previous mother's youthful, melodious voice.

"What? Oh, um, yeah. Yeah I'm good. Just, uh, still a little sleepy, that's all!" Bill faked a yawn and did his best to push out a smile.

"He shouldn't be, he slept in the entire damn morning" Gene said from the seat in front of him.

"Enough, Gene. Now, we have the tickets? Everyone got everything they need?" Tammy said, spinning in her seat after giving her husband a look.

"Tickets? Where are we going?" Bill asked, suddenly confused. He could have sworn that they were going on a road-trip! He was suddenly amused by the fact that everything that had happened in the span of thirty minutes had drastically altered his life and the lives of those around him, this was the thing that caught him entirely off guard.

"Dude, you're totally out of it!" Greg chuckled from the other side of the car, "We're flying to California, remember? Otherwise I wouldn't be here"

"It's a good thing your parents paid for your part of the trip, because then you really wouldn't be here" Gene muttered as he backed the car out onto the street a little too fast causing the tires to squeal. And then they were off, accelerating aggressively down the street as his new 'dad' clearly vented his frustration with the car.

"Yeah, thank you Mrs. and Mr. Vanapolous! We're super happy you're letting us come along! I've never been to California before, I can't wait to see the resort condo and swim in the ocean!" Martha said, and it was clear to Bill that his old mom still possessed the ability to diffuse things with her words as the look of anger on Tammy's face faded and turned back to excitement.

"Oh Martha, honey, you two kids are practically family to us, it's gonna be such a blast having you along!" Tammy turned forward for a moment before popping back around, a cellphone held up in front of her face. "Let's get you guys in a group picture!"

Bill felt Martha lean into him, her breasts bobbing to the side just enough to brush against Bill's chest as the teenage version of his mother slid an arm across his shoulder. On the other side of Martha, Greg slid into the frame as she slid her other arm across his.

"Oh, you kids look so cute! Okay, on three I want you guys to say...um..."

"Bankruptcy?" Gene muttered as he hunched over the steering wheel, but Tammy seemed to ignore him.

"Hmm, how about you guys say 'summer!', all right?" Tammy raised her finger in preparation to take the photo, "One...Two...Three!"

"SUMMER!" Martha and Greg said in unison as a flash of white light momentarily blinded Bill as his new mom took the picture. With a squeal of delight, Tammy spun the phone around to show the three teens, and Bill finally got a look at himself. HE looked entirely different!

Instead of his normal WASPy looks, now he looked very much like Gene, close cropped dark hair, large nose, almost naturally tanned skin. But his eyes were a dark, twinkling blue and he could pick out traces of what had once been Tammy's male features, when she had, once upon a time, been Tom Ackerton. Bill squeezed the gemstone in his hand, suddenly reminded of it's presence once more as the edges bit into his flesh.

'Holy shit. I look like a completely different person! I look like...like Gloria! I'm Bill Vanapolous!" Bill's mind did a somersault and he felt a twinge of anger at the injustice. In his fist, the broken Stone let out a soft glow. Bill then...

Option 1: Bill learns more about this new world, the vacation and his relationship with his teenage parents as they drive to Chicago to catch their flight.

Option 2: Bill blurts out an angry wish, forgetting about the damage to the Stone, which only makes his situation even stranger.
11412211211222112.title: A Shuffled Deck

114122112112221121.content:
Bill stared at himself on the screen of Tammy's phone, utterly shocked at his new face. He looked so different! Everyone looked different! This was insane! He subconsciously clenched the fist that held the Ahn'Ger Stone tighter as his 'mother' pulled the phone away and slid it back into her purse, trading it for a small paperback book.

"I've been wanting to catch up on my reading for a while!" She said, seeing Bill staring at her from the corner of her eye.

"I hope you don't plan on reading the whole time. If you wanted to read we could have saved on a condo" Gene said with a derisive snort as he flicked on the radio.

"Well maybe if I finish I can...tell you all about it" Tammy said, a playful tone in her voice that caused Gene's eyebrows to rise. With a soft chuckle, the former teenage girl flipped on the radio as he rest a hairy arm on the center console next to Tammy's.

"Take me hooooome, Country rooooads" Bob Denver's voice crooned from the station wagon's speakers, and Bill's mind clouded with sadness as he thought about how the morning had started. It was true what another song said, he didn't know what he had until it was gone, even if they (save for one annoying twelve year old) were all sitting nearby in the same vehicle.

As the loaded station wagon rolled out of Shermer and onto the Interstate that led towards the city of Chicago, Bill silently fumed to himself as he sat in a car full of familiar strangers. He was supposed to know each of these individuals but to him, and because of the mysterious magical gemstone in his hand, they were now all twisted. Bad enough his best friend had become his wife and then his girlfriend, but at least those wishes had come with memories!

As Gene competently weaved through the morning traffic that would only get heavily, the classic folk song faded away as the chords of another one flared to life.

"There must be some kind of way out of here said the soldier to the thief" Jimi Hendrix's signature voice called out, and suddenly the aggressive music made Bill's thoughts turn away from sadness as anger at the situation he was once again stuck in filled his mind.

"Now this is a great song!" Bill's 'dad' said from the front seat, glancing back at Bill through the rear view mirror, "Your mom and I used to listen to it all the time back in college".

"You did, dear. I was just along for the ride" Tammy said as she turned her attention to her book.

Now his best friend turned wife turned girlfriend had become Bill's mother, his best friend's bitter ex had become his father, and the two teenagers that were making small talk and surfing their phones had been his original mother and father! And this time the gemstone hadn't provided any memories on top of the huge time shift, it had simply tossed him into this reality. And Bill himself didn't even look the same! He now looked more like his new 'dad', Gloria's strong genetics making him look like a stranger himself. Anger welled up within Bill's stomach and despite the bright morning sunlight streaming into the backseat of the car and the Stone being hidden within his fist, Bill could see a shimmer of the strange light that seemed to show that the magical artifact was ready to grant a wish.

'I need to just change everything back to normal!' The Strasserman turned Vanapolous thought to himself, 'But what if it just makes it worse? No I...I need to figure it out first! Maybe then I can change everything back the right way!' Bill forced the anger in his stomach away, accepting, at least for the moment, that he was Bill Vanapolous, son of Gene and Tammy Vanapolous, and he watched as the other-worldly glow between his fingers faded away.

'Huh. So is it powered by anger? that...That actually makes a lot of sense' Bill pondered as he cautiously uncurled his fingers and exposed the now inert gemstone to the rest of the world. It glittered in the heavy morning sunlight and cast a green glow over his face as it reflected the light, and he saw Martha look over from her phone.

"Oh wow! That's really pretty Bill! Where did you get that?" She gasped, putting her phone down and sliding over in the long back seat of the station wagon, scooting almost uncomfortably close as she leaned in to stare at it.

"Where did he get what?" Greg said as he too pulled his eyes away from his own phone.

"Bill's got some kind of really pretty gemstone!" Martha said as she leaned closer onto Bill, her breasts pushing up against him as she leaned in even closer, "Wow, look at the middle! Is that real gold?"

"Gold? Bill, what the hell do you have?" Gene's voice barked in front of him and Bill saw the dark, brooding eyes that once belonged to a teenage girl staring at him suspiciously. Even Tammy turned in her seat to look at her son. In just the brief moment he'd exposed the Ahn'Ger Stone to the world it had drawn unwanted attention!

"It's nothing, mo-Martha! Just, uh, something I found in my desk last, uh, night! I thought I'd bring it along for good luck?" Bill shoved the gemstone into his pocket as quick as he could, illiciting a disappointed sigh from Martha how pulled away from Bill and went back to her phone.

"Well, it's really pretty. It'd make a beautiful necklace! And don't call me Martha, you know I like to be called Rose" The former mom said as she popped her earbuds in and pulled up a video on her phone. Bill looked over at Greg, who just stared back, his face a slight frown before his eyes darted towards Martha for a second before they too drifted back to the tiny screen in his hands. It almost looked as if his former father was...jealous?

"I think Martha is a very pretty name" Tammy said from the front seat as she turned back to her book, "It's got such a classic feel!"

"Thanks, Mrs. Vanapolous, I just prefer Rose" Martha, or rather, Rose said politely before she quickly fished a pair of earbuds out of her small purse and gave Bill a small smile before zoning off into the world of Youtube makeup blogs.

'God this is so weird. I'll have to check it out the next time I'm alone' Bill thought as he placed his hand protectively over the lump the Ahn'Ger Stone had created in his pocket. He couldn't let anything happen to it, it was his one and only ticket back to normalcy.

"Whatever it is, you better put it in your carry-on before we get on the plane, Bill. Last thing we need is you causing another delay and making us miss our flight" Gene said as he zoomed the station wagon past a row of semi-trucks.

"Yeah, they'll think you're some kind of gem thief" Greg said snarkily, "They'd have to do a cavity search" The former father and former cheerleader shared a chuckle before Tammy shushed the both of them. The car lapsed into silence as they rolled along the interstate, and Bill simply listened to the old songs that played on a loop on the XM radio station his dad had stuck the radio on.

It only took about an hour and a half to get to Chicago from Shermer, but it seemed to last forever to Bill. He kept his hand latched on the gemstone, and every now and then someone would make small talk. His new parents had eventually lapsed into talking about Gene's job, working under Jon Ingerman's father of all people, and the eventual tense silence that followed when Gene snapped at a otherwise innocent question from his wife. Eventually the silence was broken as the countryside gave way to concrete and pavement, the Chicago skyline rising above the suburbs of the outer Chicagoland metro area.

"We're almost there!" Tammy said happy, reaching back to pat Bill on the knee, "You getting excited, honey?"

"Uh, yeah. Yes. Yes I'm uh, pretty jazzed up!" Was all Bill could think of to say, earning him a half-smile as his 'mother' simply turned back to the window. Rose and Greg had pulled their faces away from their phones as they looked out the windows of the station wagon, Rose, since she was in the middle seat, alternating by leaning over Bill and Greg to get a better view, pressing up against each. of them in an almost provocative fashion.

'Is...Is mom coming onto me?' Bill thought as the younger teenage version of his mother, who in her day had been quite a beauty and now was once more, pressed up against him as Gene dove in and out of the chaotic urban traffic as he made a mad dash for the airport exit ramp, made worse by the near constant toll booths that plagued the Chicagoland area due to the trainwreck the state's budget was in.

"I told you you should have gotten over sooner!" Tammy cried out as Gene pushed the station wagon through a gap in the traffic that was just wide enough, earning him several angry honks.

"JUST LET ME DRIVE, DAMNIT" Gene roared as the exit to the airport loomed in front of them.

Option 1: The Vanapolous family and friends make it to the airport and their gate on time. While there, BIll is pulled aside by Tammy, who inadvertently fills him in on the purpose of the vacation in the hopes of improving Bill's mood.

Option 2: The Vanapolous family misses the exit and wind up in downtown Chicago on a long, time consuming detour! Gene grows ever angrier, eventually provoking Bill into making a wish that, as expected, goes horribly wrong.
114122112112221121.title: An Early Morning Family Drive

114122112112221122.content:
(Additional edits by Mr. Domino)

“Damn it!” Everyone was startled at Bill’s sudden outburst, and Gene even almost drove right off the road due to his surprise.

“What the hell Bill?!” Gene shouted.

“Why can’t this stupid stone work right?! Why does it have to screw up my entire life?! First I lost my little sister and my parents, now my best friend and his ex are my parents and my parents are my friends! And I’m the only one who realizes anything’s wrong!"

"What in the world are you talking about, Bill!? Can't you, for once, just act like a normal boy? Bad enough this trip has already busted my damn wallet, now you have to go and be weird like your sister!" Gene roared back as he twisted around in the driver seat of the car, his masculine face that had hints of Gloria still in it red with anger, a thick vein bulging from his forehead.

"GENE WATCH THE ROAD!" Tammy screamed in fear as the station wagon quickly began to drift into the other lane, prompting Gene to spin back around and violently jerk the steering wheel as the crowded car veered back onto it's side of the road. The car behind them honked angrily in protest.

"Mind your own damn business, prick!" Gene said, rolling down the window and sticking a hairy arm outwards, middle finger raised as he focused on the road once more. In the seat next to him, Tammy gave him 'the look' that usually meant he was in the doghouse as she stepped up to her son's defense.

"Gene if you can't control your temper then maybe you should just take a taxi home from the airport" Tammy said with as much of a growl as she could manage, "If you can't be civil then maybe you just shouldn't go". The threat earned her a intense glare from her husband, which she met until he finally yielded, turning back to the road with a noise that landed somewhere between a groan and a swear.

With Gene mom'd into submission, Tammy turned in her seat to look back at Bill, who was pale as a ghost and staring at the four of them in disbelief.

"Bill, sweetie, what are you talking about?" Tammy said slowly, while Martha and Greg simply stared at their friend in shock and disbelief. From the driver's seat in front of him, Bill could see the dark, angry eyes of his 'father' staring at him from the rearview mirror.

As four pairs of eyes settled on him, Bill clenched the still broken Ahn'Ger Stone tight and whispered "I wish you all remembered who you really are!” What are the effects of this new wish?

Option 1: The damaged Stone makes the wish go awry once more, as Gene and Tammy now remember being Martha and Greg...While Martha and Greg remember being Gloria and Tammy! Meanwhile, Bill suddenly starts having flashes of memories...Memories of being...his sister!?

Option 2: Gene and Tammy remember everything from all the previous realities they'd experienced that morning, while Greg and Martha remember being Bill’s parents. However, due to the Stone's damaged state, the memories are quickly shaken off and mostly forgotten save for a feeling of unease among the group.
114122112112221122.title: Tossing The Deck

choices: No fate but what we make.
114122112112222.content:
"I wish that this had never happened!" Bill roared in anger.

Green-gold light exploded from Bill's clenched fist, blinding him. He heard the twin screams of Gloria and Tammy but they vanished almost instantly, fading away to silence. He couldn't see anything, he couldn't speak, but Bill had the strange feeling that things were changing around him, and a peculiar sense of everything being..rewound?

And then reality blasted back into shape around Bill as the blinding light turned out to simply be the morning sun rising over the trees. The birds were singing, the weather was pleasantly warm and the last few banks of fog hugged the ground as they were slowly evaporated by the sun.

Bill jumped upwards in alarm, spinning around and finding himself back on his front porch. He checked his watch, his grandfather's present to him reading 7:32AM. The sounds of his mom, dad and to his relief, his little sister Kimberly coming from beyond the screen door that led into his house. And Willow was nowhere to be found.

The enormity of what just happened hit Bill like a sack of bricks, and he had to lean against the porch railing for a moment.

"Did...did I really just travel back in time?" Bill asked himself quietly. And then he spotted it. The stone that had caused everything was sitting in the exact position it had been before Bill had picked it up in the former timeline. All the chaos it had caused in just a few short moments. It had only been in his life for twenty minutes and in that time it had changed himself, his best friend, his best friend's ex into middle-aged adults. It turned his best friend into his wife, it had created a entire new reality in which he was a father. And then once again changing everything to where he was born to different parents, his best friend was his girlfriend, and his daughter from the future was now his older sister. And now a grand reset.

All that caused by a tiny gemstone, smaller than the palm of his hand. Bill suddenly realized he was reaching for the stone once more and pulled his hand away. Everything could easily go wrong all over again.

"HEY BILL!" Came a voice, and Bill looked up to see...
114122112112222.title: The Grand Rewind

1141221121122221.content:
All this has happened before, and will happen again.

In performing a grand rewind, Bill has reset his story to the beginning, though he retains his memories of the previous timeline where he, Tom and Gloria had traveled to the future.

But as with all stories, the beginning is a road to limitless adventures, and the Stone has proven to change things in unexpected ways. From this moment the timeline could repeat itself, or it could veer off into new and uncharted territory and new adventures. He still has no idea where the Ahn'Ger Stone came from and only a vague idea of how to make it work, but it is within his power to change or embrace whatever destiny it has in store for him.

Below are the three potential timelines that could have occurred at the moment Bill discovered the stone. Remember that with his knowledge of the past, these timelines will be FOREVER changed from their original paths, and can change into new adventures.

Lover's Knot: Tom or Gloria appears across the road, waving Bill over exactly as they did before.

Diary of a Stoop Kid: Bill's day of reckoning with the bullies has arrived.

Family Matters: Bill is interrupted by his sister Kimberly, or one of his parents.
