Her feet and knees already hurt from the effort of staying upright for so long this morning without support, she was a little wet from the rain, it was too hot and humid (despite it being a little on the cool side of an April morning) and she was still hungry. The cookies hadn't done anything for her, especially since she'd had to share with Brianna. Plus the scene in front of her just made her feel weird inside. She had no idea what it was but she thought the romantic scene was just gross. Also what if she caught cooties from all of this?

Meanwhile Brianna just fumed in silence as she watched the couple in front of her. She didn't like Rob at all. He was too big and muscled and she could remember when he would make fun of her, Gloria and Willow when Willow was still in high school. The mean names that he'd call her in the lunch room. And seeing Rob with Tammy, seeing how happy her much more intelligent and prettier friend seemed to be with Rob just made Brianna feel sad that she didn't have anyone, or that whenever Rob was around Tammy always spent less time with her and Gloria. The corpulent brown haired girl felt like she needed to do something about it, that she COULD do something about it, she just needed find...to find...

The painfully loud ring of the high school's bell caused Brianna's unusually thoughts to scatter into the wind once more. That was the first bell! They had to get all the way through the school to hers and Gloria's room before the second one or they'd get in trouble! Not that the two girls would have actually been punished, given their...reduced mental faculties in comparison to the rest of the student bod, but Brianna didn't have the ability to comprehend that. All she knew was that her teacher, Mrs. Orville, would be upset with her and Gloria. And Mrs. Orville was so nice to the two girls that Brianna never wanted to make her upset.

"Tammy, the bell!" Brianna croaked, causing the two lovers to part with Rob giving her an annoyed look while Tammy just stared at her in confusion before the blue eyes lit up.

"OMG! Yeah, we need to get to class!" Tammy hustled over and opened the double doors that led into the hallway that ran in front of the girl's gym. She stretched her arms out as far as she could, each door only opening so far and clearly not wide enough for the approaching twin feminine bulks. "Um, Robbie, can you help?" The blonde said over her shoulder, and her boyfriend gave her a weird look before he sighed and stomped over, taking one of the doors out of Tammy's grip and pulling it open wide as Tammy did the same with her door.

The ground shook as Gloria and Brianna's heavy footsteps came closer until they crossed through the threshold and into the school proper.

"Thanks Tammy!" Brianna said cheerfully, meanwhile Gloria simply grunted something as she wiped her perpetually sweaty forehead as the two waddled forward down the hall. Brianna...kind of knew where to go? She wanted to show everyone that she was smart like everyone else while Gloria simply followed her friend on instinct. The former queen of Shermer High didn't much care where they ended up so long as she eventually got to sit down and eat something.

"F'sure!" Tammy beamed before letting go of her door and wincing as it slammed shut with a loud CLANG while Rob's did the same. She darted over as fast as she could and reached upwards for Rob's neck, the redhead titan bending down and the two sharing a quick kiss as the blonde pulled away to do her daily duty of guiding the two girls to class. Without her they would routinely get lost in the winding corridors of Shermer High, and before Tammy had stepped in to help, Willow had been their daily escort. And she couldn't let them stop, Brianna would typically keep moving but Gloria would be a pain and a half to get walking again if they stopped.

"Baby, I'm gonna help the girls, you should get to, um, class" Tammy said as she hustled behind her charges.

"Fine. See you in a little bit." Rob called after her, watching as Tammy's gloriously large ass swished and swayed down the hall after her friends. Rob rubbed his face as the trio disappeared around the corner before he turned and began walking the other way towards his first class of the day, which thankfully was a bit of a joke class run by a joke of a teacher: Shop Class, led by Mr.Santini who was retiring at the end of the school year and thus gave zero fucks if students in his class did anything or not. Or even showed up, which suited Rob just fine.

Rob loved his schedule, and really, loved his life. In the previous reality he'd been beaten by Big Jon Ingerman, the rich kid whose dad more or less owned the town and fancied himself lord of the school. He'd beaten Rob, taken away his gang and made Rob his lackey, eeven ordering him to burn down Bill Strasserman's house as part of a final trap to get Rob out of the picture entirely and get revenge on Bill for getting him suspended. Rob had been at the Strasserman house, as ordered, but he'd planned on getting Bill to help him, to use the geek's cleverness that Rob himself had been forced to deal with more than once to take down Ingerman.

But then the Ahn'Ger Stone had tossed that reality to the wind, and now Rob Bolstrum was living his best life. Due to the damage to the Stone, the magic hadn't fully twisted Rob's mind like it had before. Instead he still distinctly remembered Bill Strasserman and Gloria Vanapolous as they had been, Seniors instead of Sophmores and smart instead of retarded. And Tammy...Tammy had been Bill's little geeky fucktoy and just as smart as him. But now...Now Bill was gone, replaced by Brianna, and Tammy was HIS. His own perfect little fucktoy, big tits, big ass, a sexy thicc bimbo that drooled all over him. Rob didn't really understand or know how any of it had happened other than a flash of green light that had whisked him away from Bill's house and dropped him off at school with a complete set of new memories, but he wasn't going to question it, not with how everything was turning out golden for him.

And as for Big Jon...Without Bill Strasserman, without the previous version of Tammy Ackerton or bitchy, vindictive Gloria, Rob's powerbase had never weakened. Big Jon was still around, but the rich bully had chosen to simply pay for Rob's services rather than take control of the Shermer bullies himself. And Big Jon paid well. Rob (and to a lesser extent, the rest of the bullies) were earning shitloads of cash by being Ingerman's enforcers. And at this point that basically meant that Rob could do whatever he wanted with little fear of repercussion so long as nothing blew back onto Big Jon.

Rob wasn't even living in the trailer court anymore! With the money he was now making Rob had been able to rent an apartment in Old Shermer. It wasn't the best, but it was his and it was cheap. And it meant that he could get shitfaced drunk as often as he wanted, and more importantly, fuck Tammy on a regular basis without interference from her parents (who tolerated him simply because they loved and spoiled their daughter, and allowed him to eat with them most nights).

'And who doesn't love free meals?' Rob thought with a chuckle as he stomped into the Shop room, where the rest of his gang was waiting, including his own right hand man, Jules Harper.

"Hey boss, you finally get tired of, heh, pounding dough?" Jules snickered, sending a wave of good-natured chuckles through the assembled gang. Before Rob would have been pissed, but now he simply took the ribbing with a wry grin. The boys respected him and in this new reality, liked to give him shit about Tammy being on the heavy side.

"Call your mom and see, shithead!" Rob jeered back, and the entire group erupted into raucous laughter.

'Yeah' Rob thought as he oversaw his little kingdom, 'It's good to be the king again'

11412211211222333333.content:
No one noticed that despite being an impossibly powerful artifact, the Ahn'Ger Stone was not invulnerable. It was still simply a gemstone, just one with otherworldly powers that could bend and shape reality on command. And when Bill's attack on Gloria caused her to fling the Ahn'Ger Stone down the hallway, it had cracked. In the heat of the moment Bill had no idea that the artifact in his hand was damaged.

With his wish, the power coursing through the stone was not released safely or in a way that obeyed the rules that bound the stone to it's purpose. Not even it, if the stone did or did not possess such an ability, could guess at what would happen when Bill's wish was granted.

Whatever Bill wished for next was going to go utterly, horribly wrong no matter how he said it.

"I wish..."

Option 1: "...That you'd take a long walk off a short pier!" As a result of the damage to the Stone, the magical energy is unable to target Gloria specifically and instead targets everyone. As a result, the world has been changed into a romanticized version of the Age of Sail and Piracy. Instead of Midwest America, Bill finds himself on-board a ship on the high seas, along with Tammy, Willow, and Gloria, who was about to walk the plank!

Option 2: "...That you'd buzz off!" As a result of the damage to the Stone, the magical energy is unable to target Gloria specifically, instead lashing out at random, transforming more than just Gloria. As the light from the Ahn'Ger Stone fades, Gloria has been transformed into a fly! But wait, something was really, really wrong!
11412211211222333333.title: Bill makes additional wishes. (More Options)

114122112112223333332.content:
Bill gripped the Ahn'Ger Stone tightly, so tight that he felt the edges of the gemstone painfully digging into his palm, even feeling a warm trickle of blood from where the pointed edge had clearly broken the skin. He didn't care though, he was too angry to care. Gloria had to pay for what she'd done. She'd changed Tom into Tammy, made Tammy his wife, made them old, gave them a daughter and then had brought them back to their proper ages only with his ENTIRE family messed up! His mother and father were entirely different people (still named Strasserman, but looked entirely different. Even Bill looked different due to his new parentage, but it seemed like none of the gathered teens or Bill himself had noticed the slight change to appearance) and had erased his little sister Kimberly from existence and had replaced her with his future daughter!

All of that, and Bill hadn't even gotten to USE the Stone, which had come to HIM first!

And then Gloria, that self-righteous egotistical little BITCH had run her mouth again and placed the straw that finally broke Bill's patience. He'd slapped Gloria, the pretty dark haired girl grabbing her face in shock as the magical rock flew down the upstairs hallway of the Strasserman household, causing it to unknowingly crack as it hit the wall. Bill had grabbed it before anyone else could and with the furious anger of a small star, focused on the one thing he wanted right now more than anything else: He wanted Gloria Vanapolous out of his house.

However, due to the damage to the Ahn'Ger Stone, not a single one of the collected teens knew that any wish made on it now would go horribly, horribly wrong no matter how much anger was channeled into the wish-granting artifact. And perhaps it was just Bill's own anger clouding his mind or perhaps the influence of the Stone itself, he phrased his first wish poorly, not knowing the consequences of what would happen.

"I WISH YOU'D JUST BUZZ OFF, GLORIA!" Bill roared, and with a flash of light and a deafening ringing noise, the world was changed as the STone's magic reached out and touched not just Gloria Vanapolous, but the world as well. Gloria barely had time to let loose a shriek as she felt her body begin to change.

And as the light subsided and the world swam back into focus for Bill, he smiled at the result. Before him, exactly in the spot where Gloria had been standing and in all of her grotesque glory, was a fat, hairy fly, large red compound eyes staring emotionlessly out at the world while a slimy probuscis slithered in and out of her insectoid head. A set of wings twitched along a swollen abdomen while her six new legs rubbed themselves together on instinct. She was bloated and looked diseased, and Bill couldn't be more thrilled at the result. He'd just wanted the bitchy teen to leave but seeing her as a disgusting insect was so much more satisfying, to see he get a taste of her own medicine.

Of course, that was when he realized something had gone horribly, horribly wrong.

Option 1: Bill realizes that Gloria is still human sized and can talk! In fact it seemed as if every single human on Earth had been changed by Bill's wish, becoming a variety of enormous, intelligent insects that seemed to befit their inner personality! Bill himself was an ant! And not just any ant, but a QUEEN ant! And Tammy was a butterfly! As Bill comes to grips with what his wish had done, he realizes the Stone had been damaged!

Option 2: Gloria is now a regular sized house fly, but so are Bill and Tammy! Only Bill seems to have retained his mind as the two female flies quickly buzz off in search of food in the Strasserman household, while Bill is left stunned, wondering what went wrong. Then he sees the Ahn'Ger Stone laying on the carpet next to him, and the giant crack on it's side! How was he going to wish himself, Tammy and Gloria back now!?

1141221121122233333323.title: Feeling Buggy: Additional Options

114122112112223333333.content:
No one knew that the Stone was damaged. No one knew that no matter what Bill wished, it was going to do crazy, unpredictable changes to reality on a scale that it had truly yet to inflict. That was when Bill made his wish and the Ahn'Ger Stone flashed with light, blinding everyone in the Strasserman home and morphing the entire world around them. There was no telling what it would do, no tiny little prompts in the back of Bill's mind playing like a projector, no god figure on high pulling the strings of their newest little puppet in the Multiverse. There was no telling what would happen.

No, there was just the Stone, badly damaged, and the raging, raw fire of emotion that fueled the magic, pulled from places unknown.

As Bill squeezed his fist tight around the Stone, so hard that the curved edges bit deep into his flesh and causing a small river of blood to ruin the upstairs hallway carpet, he made his wish.

"I wish..."
114122112112223333333.title: Bill makes additional wishes. (Options, Optional)

1141221121122233333331.content:
"I WISH THAT YOU WERE DEAD!" Bill screamed in rage, spit flying from his mouth as he snarled at Gloria. And then it was done. There was no blinding flash of light, no magical cloud of smoke, nothing to obscure Bill's vision, no crack of thunder or ray of light to signify the wish had been granted. There was only the sound of Bill's own heavy breathing as he stared hatefully at the girl who had ruined everything.

And then Gloria merely collapsed on the floor, her eyes rolled into the back of her head. Nearby in the sudden, absolute stillness, Tammy's body fell to the floor in a lifeless heap. Horns began blaring from below, outside, from everywhere. The sound of tires screeching and the scream of twisting metal. Explosions. The sudden lack of sound from the TV new program that Bill's new family had clearly left on downstairs. Thuds on the roof of the house as things began to fall out of the sky.

In Bill's hand, still clutched tightly around the Stone, still held towards Gloria's crumpled body, still bleeding, something shifted. The sudden change snapped Bill out of his red-fueled haze. His entire body was stiff, his muscles taking their time to un-clench and the pain in his jaw an teeth pulsing as he released them. The red faded, the adrenaline capped, and Bill fell to the floor, his breath heavy and ragged in his chest as he opened his closed fist, wondering where the blood dripping out of it had come from.

And there, it two distinct pieces, was the Ahn'Ger Stone. Whatever inner light it had possessed was gone, the inner gemstone, if it even was a gemstone, crumbling to golden dust and mixing with BIll's blood slowly dripping into the carpet.

"W-what? I..." Was all the teenager could mutter as he started as the broken gemstone in disbelief before casting a terrified look at the motionless bodies of Gloria Vanapolous and Tammy Ackerton.

"Oh, oh god" Bill said as the contents of his stomach made a mad dash up his throat, hot and burning as breakfast and bile spilled out on to the carpet, the now destroyed artifact tumbling out of his grip and onto the carpet. When the contents of his stomach had ceased rising, he began to dry heave, pain wracking his body as panic and fear began to merge into shock. He vision tunneled and he heard himself wheezing, before he tumbled to his side, curling up into a tight ball, his eyes closed as he silently wished to take it all back.

A nearby, VERY loud explosion pulled him from his shock a few moments later, and as the entire Strasserman house shook violently from the shockwave, Bill managed to crane his neck to see the top of a nearby plume of fire and smoke cresting in the hallway window. He pulled himself up, trying his best not to look at the two bodies laying in his hallway, mere feet from his bedroom as he struggled to make his suddenly filled with cement legs move. When Bill eventually made it to the window, other plumes of fire and smoke were rising in the distance as the thunderclaps of explosions echoed into the distance.

And below him was something out of a movie. Bodies were everywhere, cars over turned, pedestrians laying on the sidewalks where they had been walking. Bodies in parked cars. And not just human bodies. There was a carpet of deceased wildlife as far as Bill could see as another plane dropped from the heavens and crashed in the distance. Masses of squirrels, birds, dogs cats, raccoons. Even insects were not spared from Bill's wrathful wish as a spider in the window hung limply in it's web, a half-spun insect dangling next to it. Even the trees, plants and grass seemed to be affected, the brilliant greenery of springtime turned lifeless and dull, fronds and limbs drooping low as leaves began to simply release themselves from the branches they had just grown onto.

"Oh god. Oh, oh god" Was all BIll said before the stress of it broke his mind, and he collapsed to the floor unconscious as all life ended around him.
1141221121122233333331.title: Option 1

11412211211222333333311.content:
Years passed.

Bill grew, unlike everything else around him. The Strasserman had grown accustomed to the silence of his new world. The unchanging world. The world of the dead. And it truly was the world of the dead, as not even bacteria seemed to have survived. Nothing rotted, though the stench of billions upon billions of bowels reflexively emptying and the constant smell of smoke and ash from the still raging fires had nearly driven him insane. Or had. At some point Bill reconciled that if no one was already to tell him he was crazy, then he obviously couldn't be.

When he woke up, lungs burning he breathed in smoke, he had barely enough time to scramble out of his home as a raging fire engulfed it. His immediate reaction as he watched home burn was that he had left the Stone in there, in his frantic scramble to get outside. His one chance, the only thing that he knew that could fix it, was gone in the blaze. And then his thoughts turned, he had leftTammy and Willow in there, that if nothing else he needed to bury them, but there was simply no way he could brave the inferno that was quickly consuming his neighborhood. So Bill had dashed into the garage, tried not to collapse as he pulled Willow's lifeless body out of her car, and took off in the direction of anywhere else that wasn't on fire. Eventually he simply headed out into the forests, moving car to car as one ran out of gas. Eventually he had gotten far enough from the remains of civilization that the air cleared and smoke and fires faded away into absolute silence. He'd lived out of an intact resort for awhile before he noticed it.

The air was getting thinner. At first Bill had chalked it up to simply higher altitude, he had passed through so many states fleeing from the fires that he had come across mountains. But eventually he had to forage in the lowlands, and that's when he realized that if the trees, if all plants were also dead, there was no more oxygen being produced.

Suddenly his priorities for survival had changed from 'find food' to 'keep breathing'. He'd gone from a reaper robbing the graves he had created to a desperate ghoul, prowling through hospitals, elderly homes, anywhere that would have a breath of air in a world that was quickly becoming airless. The irony hadn't been lost on Bill that the search for oxygen was a self-defeating endeavor, the more he searched, the more he needed to breathe, and the more he needed to breathe, the harder he had to search.

And Bill knew that eventually, he'd join the corpses. Eventually he'd run out of hospitals, retirement homes, supplies.

And one day, after Bill had grown into a man, muscled, raggedy, poorly clothed and bathed, that he did. Prying open a crate of crate in the ruins of Los Angeles, the last oxygen tank Bill had went dry. He ripped off his mask and gasped in the toxic atmosphere, hands pawing weakly at the crate in front of him as salty tears stung his eyes.

And then he was gone, a single, raspy gasp in a silent world as the final living being on the planet Earth died. But not just on Earth, Bill's wish had reached across the entire universe, snuffing out life, and was continuing to snuff out life as the wish magic traveled the stars.

Bill had become Death, the Destroyer of Worlds. But even Death had to die. And so he did.
11412211211222333333311.title: The Last One.

11412211211222333333312.content:
Bill woke coughing. His lungs were on fire, his eyes stinging as smoke filled them. With a hacking cough the teenager pulled himself upright as his brain completed a very fast, hard restart. What was going on!?

And then the memories came back. He'd killed everyone. A stupid wish that murdered everyone and everything and had caused the Stone to shatter. And then an explosion...and fire! Bill had no time to process anything but survival as he bolted upright and stumbled through the smoke, he feet knocking against the lifeless body of...someone. He was pretty sure it was Gloria, but he couldn't concern himself with that. Instead he stumbled down the stairs trying his best not to breathe in any more smoke, crashing through the front door and into the front yard. The low, ominous rumble of fire burned behind him as Bill coughed the ash and smoke out of his lungs before flopping backwards, watching his home burn.

All around him the neighborhood burned, a suburban inferno. Dead bodies of people and animals surrounded him and he could smell the sickeningly sweet smell of meat cooking as fire washed over prone bodies.

"I did this" Bill whispered to no one but himself. There was no one left to whisper to. No one left to love or hate, ignore. There was only him. And what point was there to staying alive? To suffer a horrible solitary existence moving from one location to the next, staying ahead of fires while looking for food? What kind of a life was lived entirely alone?

"I'm so sorry" Bill said. And with that, overcome by the loss of everything and everyone he had ever known, Bill stood and raced back into his home as it collapsed into a cloud of smoke and embers. The heat and pain was intense as he flesh was stripped away by flame, and his brain simply cooked away, leaving Bill another charred pile of ash the world of the dead.
11412211211222333333312.title: Unable to Cope.

choices: There was a clinking sound on the far end of the car's dashboard.
11412211211222333333313.content:
It was the smoke that woke Bill from the blackness. A formless world of darkness that had suddenly become very warm as the fire from the nearby plane crash had quickly spread across Bill's neighborhood and had nearly engulfed the Strasserman home before Bill's lungs had alarmed him to the danger. Snapping upright, his mind performing a hard reboot in a matter of seconds, Bill stumbled through the smoke, his feet catching on one of the two bodies that were up there with him. He was pretty sure it was Gloria, and he paused just long enough to see a glimmer of green through the smoke.

"THE STONE!" Bill coughed, and he pushed his way through the smoke to find the two pieces of the Ahn'Ger Stone, inches away from the roaring blaze. Risking catching himself on fire, Bill scopped the two broken pieces up in his hand and with a final look through the deadly glood at where Tammy's body was obscured, he shot down the stairs and crashed through the front doors, hacking and coughing, eyes stinging as the entire building imploded behind him.

"H-holy shit!" Bill gasped, sparing a look at the ruins of his home before seeing just how deadly the inferno had become. The entire neighborhood was on fire, every single building a blaze as the fire spread uncontained or uncontrolled. Realizing that he still wasn't safe, Bill clutched the ruined artifact close to his chest and stumbled out onto the street towards a pink car that he didn't recognize. The driver was some girl around Willow's age, pretty, if it weren't for the slack look of death on her face. Bill had no time to worry about that as he pulled the corpse from the car, trying hard not to be overwhelmed with what he had done, letting the girl fall to the sidewalk with a unceremonious thud as he climbed in the driver seat and turned the ignition. Hot coffee spared Bill's seared nostrils the smell of smoke for one moment, and a low fat donut lay beside it.

"I'm sorry" Was all Bill whispered as the ignition growled to life and the lone survivor of the kiss of death quickly, but carefully made his way down the street, the entire world looking like something you'd expect out of an apocalypse film.

"Only those don't actually happen" Bill thought grimly to himself as he navigated the treacherous route, rolling past massive multi-car wrecks, burning cars, and cars that were just stopped where their drivers had perished. And everything was on fire. There was no end to the fire. No matter how far into town he went, and no matter how far into the suburbs and the more rural areas of Shermer that Bill drove, everything was, to some level, on fire. Eventually Bill just decided to head west, surely somewhere out there was a place that wouldn't be touched by endless flame.

And he drove for a long while. State signs passed him by, but he paid no attention. It didn't matter anymore. The car ran out of gas, so he simply took another one, the occupant having unfortunately released his bowels within. And the silence was deafening. There were no sounds outside of the car's engine. No birdsong, no insects chirping, nothing, especially once he had made it away from any inhabited areas. The radio was nothing but a endless loop of static, though the satellite channels still played music on an automated loop, advertisements for businesses and services that were no longer operating due to everyone being, well, dead.

Bill's urge to run eventually gave out, and he pulled into what he assumed was some sort of park next to a creek. It was there, finally away from the danger and at least some form of natural sound from the rippling water allowed him to break down into a long, hard cry, his body and mind finally breaking under the strain. He wasn't sure how long he cried, but the day had turned to twilight before he was finally able to pull himself together, and he fished the remains of the Stone out of his pocket, staring at the broken fragments. Out of desperation, Bill pressed the two pieces together, noticing for the first time the massive crack that didn't match up with the stress fractures caused by his crushing grip.

"Is...this what did it?" Bill whispered, and suddenly realized there was no need. No one was around to hear his secret. No one at all.

"christ...There has to be a way to fix this, there has to be!" Bill hissed as anger rose in his gut. For a moment he thought he might have seen a glimmer from the destroyed artifact, but try as he might it never appeared again. Any wishes Bill made went ungranted, and the teenager had to come to terms with being the only thing alive on the entire planet.

"This...This just cannot be happening" Bill said to the dark night around him, a glow in the distance as the city engulfing fires burned on. "there has to be some kind of way out of this mess!"

That was when...
11412211211222333333313.title: Futile Effort.

choices: Stick to what he knew, the Ahn'Ger Stone
Taking a risk and leaping into someone else's storyline.
114122112112223333333131.content:
It was the pit of despair that Bill found himself in, the last living thing alive in a dead universe where the only other thing that seemed to be active was the inferno inadvertently caused by the teenager's wish. In a stranger's car so far away from his now destroyed home. Utterly and completely alone, with only the radio waves full of ghosts to keep him company. He clutched the broken artifact in his hands and openly sobbed at how trapped he seemed, how wrong everything had gone. If he had just controlled his rage, if he had simply kept the Stone hidden from Gloria, all of this could have been avoided.

The pain and anguish he felt was crushing. A large part of him wanted to simply bust one of the car's windows and slit his wrists and throat, to join the mountain of corpses, the reaper claiming one last victim to complete it's work. The rest of him just felt like curling into a ball and sobbing until he physically could no longer do so. Bill eyed the jagged edge of the broken Ahn'Ger Stone. It looked sharp enough.

'Why ruin a perfectly good car?' Bill thought as he raised the sharper, less jagged of the two fragments to his left wrist and pressed the cold gemstone against his flesh, closing his eyes as he tensed his right arm, bracing himself for the pain that was about to go through his body.

"I'll see you soon, everyone" Bill whispered, and with a sharp inhale, pulled the gem across his wrist, waiting for the flare of pain and the feeling of warm blood. Yet nothing came. Confused, Bill opened his eyes to see that he was no longer holding the Stone fragments. And then he heard it, a slight click of something very close by landing on the hard plastic that framed the car's dashboard. Bill looked towards the sound and saw...

...A fairy? Or something close to it. It was crystalline, though there was no one color to it. Instead every color of the rainbow shined like a prism as the small, winged creature sat in a half-crouch, tiny face watching him with what looked like a morbid grin.

"Getting a little...edgy there, aren't you, Bill?" The fairy asked, it's voice male and female at the same time, as if two people were trying to talk one moment ahead and behind each other. It made Bill's head hurt. The fairy stood and fluttered it's large wings, a network of crystal latticework that caused it to float towards the confused teen with the slight sound of grinding stone. Bill instinctively pushed himself against the driver side door of the car, and the fairy stopped, slid a hand to it's palm and sighed in annoyance.

"Listen, Bill, we're both here because you fucked up and you're not dealing with it very well. I mean, you're doing better than the other version of you who decided to cosplay as pot roast..." In the empty framing of one of the fairy's wings, a impossibly clear image of Bill running back into his house as it collapsed, allowing himself to die, the grisly detail as his body cooked and sizzled in the extreme heat.

"Oh fuck" Bill's eyes went wide at watching himself die, "But, I didn't do that!" The fairy rolled it's eyes again and struck a pose that, if Bill had been paying any sort of attention, looked remarkably like Gloria when she was being catty.

"It's called the Multiverse, sweetheart. You did that in another universe. In another..." The fairy flicked another wing and a picture of three identical versions of Gloria were fighting over the Stone on the sidewalk outside of the Vanapolous house. And another showed Bill and Tammy holding hands on the front porch sharing a soft kiss. And another showed a female version of Bill clinging tight to a very male Tom as they walked to school, hands clasped together and not a single sign that that version of Bill remained behind the girl's eyes.

But Bill's eyes flickered back to the scene showing him running into the blazing fire of his house and killing himself via immolation, and he couldn't help but shudder. The fairy flicked it's wings and the images vanished, shrugging it's tiny arms dramatically.

"I know, right? Really fucking edgelord shit in that one. I mean at least in...well, most of the other ones, nothing bad happens. Yet. Those timelines are still being explored...But yeah, that one version of you really overreacted. It's not like any of this doesn't really matter anyway. Fucking tryhard" The fairy scoffed as it floated through the car's interior.

"Wait, what do you mean 'doesn't really matter'?" Are you here to undo the wish? Can you make everything normal again!?" Bill's mind began racing. Perhaps this fairy, or whatever it was, was sent by the same thing that had given him the Stone! Maybe it was some sort of cosmic maid!

"Listen, I'm gonna skip the long explanation. No, I'm not here to just reverse everything..That's not how it works. Well, aside from the one reality, but even then things don't go back to the way everything started. That makes it too easy to repeat the same mistakes, to tell the same story without any variation, which causes closed loops where the reality just constantly repeats" The fairy, seemingly bored with floating, took a seat on the passenger side headrest. "No, you have to live with these choices. But I'm told to offer you a way out of this particular reality, at least. The other two timelines caused by this have already ceased to operate and those Bills are dead. But you're alive, so instead of just let you tell the same story of being a wimp and killing yourself or struggling against unbeatable odds, here's what's going to happen.

The fairy stood, spread it's wings wide, and the latticeworks of it's wings intensified, more and more...Bill couldn't help but compare them to screens, appearing that showed so many realities playing out before him. Other version of him with his friends and family, in one Gloria was apparently his dog? Most of this new set, however, Bill didn't even recognize, some focused entirely on people he didn't know. One seemed to be tethered to a Remote, other,s a two families going on vacation...And two guys messing around with tools?

"Yeah, I know" The fairy said, rolling it's eyes again. "Seems dumb, but since there's nothing left in this timeline, you get to jump ship to another. They can either be one of your realities, or they can be the reality of someone else's story. I'm not really supposed to tell you this, but basically if you choose any of your timelines, you're gonna constantly just get screwed over. You may keep the Stone, you may lose it, but you almost always end up suffering because of it Huh, I wonder if that's the point..." The fairy floated off for a moment, turning away from Bill as it seemed lost in thought.

"Ahem" Bill said after a long moment of silence, and the fairy jumped in mid-air, turning back to him.

"Whoops! Yeah, sorry. Basically you go back into one of your realities, there's already a Bill there. You can't inhabit the same space. You'll be someone else, but it'll be a life that you're...well, everyone you know is alive, at least. IF you choose any of the OTHER realities, it's not your story anymore. You'll be back in a living world, you might even be allowed to be you, but you'll no longer be the main character. Maybe. Or you can stay here and ignore the offer from 'on high'" The fairy paused again and looked up at the ceiling of the car with an eyebrow raised, "And die like you do in the other two realities. Word of advice though, if you choose the edgelord option, try to make it interesting? No one likes repeat performances"

Bill's mind buzzed with information. There was...some form of a chance to fix his mess. Or escape it? Bill wasn't quite sure, but anything had to be better than here. He could be someone else with a different life, the burden of having infinite and very easily abused power no longer around his shoulders like an anchor. But one question still remained....

"But what are you?" Bill asked the fairy, who was somersaulting itself in the air despite physics not working like that.

"Consider me a life ring. And yes, I'm sent by the same thing that sent the Ahn'Ger Stone" The fairy rolled it's eyes at the confusion on Bill's face, "The Stone. The shiny green thing that only granted wishes when you were angry. That was the name. And no, I can't tell you anything about where I came from. That breaks what little remains of the rules. Can't give away all the secrets."

"I see..."

"You don't, but we're starting to run short on time here. I highly suggest you take what time I've got left to think about your choices. I can show any available reality that you can enter, sort of like endless TV channels. When you've picked one, all you've got to do is touch it and you'll pass into that reality and whatever new life is waiting. Sound good? Because I'm tired of talking and flying. I'm gonna sit here on the dash while you make your choice"

'Well, points off for being a rude little shit' Bill thought, and the fairy held up a tiny little finger, almost as if it had read his mind. Not wanting to tempt fate

"Which is a really good idea, I might add" The fairy said, interrupting Bill's train of thought once more.

"FINE!" Bill said, frustration boiling over as he sat angrily back in the car seat and began viewing the realities available to him, swiping through them like pictures on a cellphone. Before long, he decided too...
114122112112223333333131.title: The Escape Clause

choices: Keep searching, maybe he'd find one that was 'closer to home'.
1141221121122233333331311.content:
Bill scrolled through so many realities, swiping his finger through the air in front of the fairy whose fancy had gone from impatient to flat out bored. There were so many choices, so many worlds, full of strangers in strange places before he finally decided that trying to jump into a entirely new place with no friends or family that was just too much of a hassle. He wanted familiarity, his friends and family back, even if, according to the fairy, things might be slightly askew for him personally. But anything was better than trapped, surrounded by fire and death. If none of the realities centered on him seemed safe or fit, Bill would still be happy to go with something new.

"Can...Can you just give me all the choices from MY reality?" Bill asked the fairy.

"Well, they're not YOUR realities. Just ones you're familiar with. But yeah, I can do that" The fairy fluttered it's wings and the images of all the different and strange realities disappeared as those revolving around the Ahn'Ger Stone flickered into view.

"Thanks" Bill didn't want to offend the one chance he had at escaping by not being polite, but the fairy just shrugged.

"Whatever"

With that, Bill began to scroll once more. Here, there was a reality where he...Well, he looked like Willow and was snuggled against an older version of what looked like Gloria. There were subtle differences, but the resemblance was incredibly strong. But what caught his attention more than anything was the fact the two seemed to be orbit the planet Saturn!

"weird" Bill said, looking at another option.

Here was one where Bill was, once again, a woman while Rob Bolstrum and what looked like a walking wetdream had him cornered in one of the hallways at school, the Stone flashing triumphantly in Rob's hand.

"Don't want that one.." Bill said

"Yeah, because spoiler alert, you'd be the little brainless whore that trog has wrapped around him."

"What"

"I did say spoilers. Ironically enough it's a reality where you would have actually been yourself, if slightly idealized. Stronger, more popular, the whole jock stereotype. But doesn't end well for you"

"You're so weird, you know that, right?" Bill said as he watched that particular version of himself shove a tongue down Rob's throat before the Willow version of himself lashed out at the Stone, seizing it and turning Rob and the whore version of himself into statues.

"Yeah, well...blame the editor" The Fairy said, point a finger to the roof of the car.

Another reality was Bill being confronted by Rob again...And becoming a chicken? And then a really gross chicken lady married to Tom, who looked like a rooster? And his entire family being very strange humanizations of barnyard animals?

"I always liked that one, simply because of how weird it was" The fairy replied, chuckling to itself. Bill just rolled his eyes.

There were so many options to choose from. HEre, stuck as a little girl with Kimberly and his dad, another where he and Kimberly switched bodies and simply accepted it? Another version where HE was Gloria's mom, Tom was his second daughter and Gloria's real mom was Bill's youngest child!

"That must be a nightmare" Bill muttered.

"Nah. Well, yeah. But it's fun to watch the other version of you become that. I have no idea where you'd end up there, though. None of the main characters in that reality remember who they used to be, including that version of yourself. Eventually you just sort of...go to work and be a bitch to your underlings. Started fun, ended blandly"

"and what about this one?" Bill said, pointing to a screen below the weird...chickenwoman one. It showed Rob running rampant with the Stone, causing chaos without end as the bully became ruler of the world, fighting demons and any other manner of foolishness before two men in black showed up.

"Eh...It just sort of becomes a power fantasy. I mean all of these are power fantasies based around the desire to change your reality with a wish, but that one more so than the others. He ends up trapped forever in...you ever see the original Superman II?"

Bill shook his head. His preferred version of Superman was the one in Man of Steel, the old movies were just too campy for him.

"Well, the bad guy gets locked away in this mirror thing and shot off into some alternate dimension. Same thing happens to the trog, he fucks up because he's an idiot. Again, no idea where you'd fit into that world"

Bill chuckled, and despite himself, found he was having a little bit of fun, despite the fact he was still in a reality that he had essentially murdered all life. "Yeah, Rob's an idiot. The biggest one I know"

"Well...I mean, there's several more recent realities, your current one included, where he's smarter. Still a bit of a blockhead, but he had to become smarter because of the new addition"

Bill, for some reason, felt a strange sense of actually having something spoiled for him, but he couldn't resist. The fairy was clearly talking about the world Bill inhabited right now. "What do you mean, 'new addition'?"

"Jonathan Ingerman. If you look through most of these you'll see it's just Rob Bolstrum. 'Big Jon' is someone new to this particular selection of realities"

Bill just blinked in amazement.

"Anyway, you gonna pick something or are you just gonna reality surf all night? I've got places to be also, you know" The fairy said, tapping it's foot against the dashboard.

Bill decided to...
1141221121122233333331311.title: Stick to what he knew, the Ahn'Ger Stone

choices: Bill chooses another Ahn'Ger Stone reality.
11412211211222333333313112.content:
Bill thought for a moment, and decided to ask the Fairy one more question.

"How many realities are there to choose from in this list?" Bill reasoning was that while all of these looked interesting, well, they were also a bit weird. It might be better to continue searching for one where he was better off. But the Fairy seemed to know what BIll was planning as it fixed him with a 'seriously?' look.

"Kid, it's the Multiverse. That means an infinite number of realities stacked next to each other. You've not even looked at 0.01% of the first group yet. That's how many there are. So if you're not picking these, keep looking because, spoiler, there's only a finite amount of time that you'll be able to live in this reality, given your wish also killed off the planet's plant life that create the oxygen you need to breathe" The Fairy began inspecting it's nails again as Bill jaw went slack.

"W-what!?" Was all Bill could say.

"Have you not been paying attention? Everything died apart from you. That means eventually you're gonna start running out of air" The Fairy pointed to a 'screen' in it's wing that switched from showing another Bill pleading with a grown woman that had moments ago before been a unknown teenage boy to a much older, adult version of Bill gasping for air in the ruins of a city as the oxygen tank he was carrying ran dry.

"That's what happened to the other Bill that made the same wish you did, only he decided to tough it out while the other version went crispy critter. You in particular get a ticket out. So sure, you can keep trying to find that absolute 'perfect' reality for as long as you want, but you're on a time table"

The information stunned Bill for a moment. This world really was all th way dead, and eventually he would be as well. But he had a choice of infinite timelines at the choosing...But that also meant that there would never be a end before HE ended. The Fairy was right, Bill had to choose.

"Fine, but can I get like a list or something of the ones I've already looked at? Hard to keep track of them all"

The Fairy snapped it's fingers and the 'screens' within it's wings folded away, the crystalline latticeworks collapsing in on themselves until the gaps between the Fairy's wings were large. And there, a list of text began to form.

"And when you're ready, just tap on the one you want and i'll open the portal to that reality. And if you simply just cannot make up your mid, just swipe like you did before, and more realities will show up in the list. Might be more fun that way, total surprise"

Bill leaned in close to the Fairy. Despite the fact that it had enlarged it's wings to make room for the text, said text was still quite small. It was a little hard to read,but Bill began to read down the list.

Far Beyond the Stars
Defiance
Barnyard Bill
The Strasserman Triplets
Rob Triumphant


"Why do they have titles?" Said Bill, suddenly confused again. The Fairy snorted derisively.

"Because the Editor has a thing about defining different realities so that they're easier to find. Every reality has it's own name, and these are just the first few that you looked at"

"Oh" Was all Bill could think to say. After a few more moments, Bill decided to pick one of these new realities.
11412211211222333333313112.title: Reality Slider

114122112112223333333131121.content:
Bill still had trouble deciding which reality would be the most comfortable to live in. So he closed his eyes and went through the options one more time, weighing which ones were the least preferable.

"Definitely don't want the chicken lady one" he whispered to himself as he wiped sweat off his brow. "I definitely don't want the one where I'm Rob's bitch. I definitely don't want one with an all powerful Rob Bolstrum running around. So that leaves two."

The strange fairy waited impatiently, tapping its crystalline feet as the unintentional harbinger of doom made up his mind.

"The little girl one or the space one. The little girl one might be OK. I can fake being Kimmy's sister for a while until I fix the stone. The space one is weird as hell. Why am I with Gloria of all people? Where's Tammy? Where's everyone else? Are they dead? Is it the future? Why am I Willow?"

Bill was giving himself anxiety as he asked himself these questions. Outside the stolen car, several large oak trees had suddenly collapsed in tandem upon several now vacant homes as the ravaging fire continued to spread across Shermer. Despite the homes being far enough away to be out of sight of Bill, the crash had created a crashing noise so deafening, it finally shook the teenage boy out of his indecision. He opened his eyes.

"Well that's a wake up call if I heard one" answered the fairy in a dry tone as the androgynous being continued to tap it's feet to a staccato melody. "The clock is ticking, buddy."

"OK OK OK! I'll pick the space one!" Bill said in a rush, finally accepting the magnitude of what his wish had done. Bill had singlehandedly destroyed the Earth. Humanity, in all its two hundred thousand year history(Give or take), hadn't been finally done in by global warming. Not by nuclear winter. Not an asteroid impact or a caldera explosion or a vaccine resistant super flu. It was one lone eighteen year old boy, barely an adult and for all intents and purposes not one, who had rung the bell. Massive pangs of guilt were plaguing his brain as he remembered the motionless bodies of Tammy and Gloria laying in his family home, knowing that he was the one who had killed them. Bill began to well up with tears as he selected the option furthest to the left of the array of incorporeal TV like screens.

FAR BEYOND THE STARS said the selected option in small blocky letters in the caption below.

Bill touched the screen, feeling a clicking sensation like the pressing of a button. He watched the screen expand to encompass the fairy's entire wingspan. The Willow version of himself and the older version of Gloria seemed to be discussing something important.

"I feel like I'm staring into a crystal ball."

The fairy nodded its diminutive little head.

"Why this one?" it asked softly, surprised by his decision. The fairy was sure that Bill would go for The Strasserman Triplets.

Bill sniffled through an answer.

"I've always wanted to go into space. I never thought I'd have a chance to. I...I wanted to be an astronaut when I...I was little. Gave... gave up on...on it" he said as he fought back tears. "I convinced myself it was too hard. Living on... living on a spaceship orbiting Saturn is the next best thing, I suppose. Plus, the Earth has had its day" he chuckled grimly, in shock as the fire continued to claim his small town.

The heat in the car was now unbearable. Bill felt like he was baking in an oven. He saw the modest body of water he was parked next to. He had ridden past it on his bicycle so many times growing up, never giving it a second thought. It looked so beautiful now.

The magical benefactor glared at Bill with what the teenager had confused with sympathy.

"Try not to screw this reality up so bad, honey. I'm not coming back a second time if you do" it answered flatly as it flew over to Bill and touched his forehead with its tiny hand. Everything went dark.

**

Bill Strasserman chuckled as she poured herself a cup of Venusian coffee and stared outside of the viewport of her kitchen into the blackness of the solar system, her body wrapped in a comfortable fluffy white bathrobe. The rings looked so beautiful this time of morning.

She

It had been over four years since Bill had been blessed(Or cursed) with the Grellstone, and it was finally now, during this moment alone, when the former teenage boy was finally comfortable using female pronouns on himself...or herself, rather. She had finally come to terms with her identity issues, at least the biggest chunk of them.

In the back of her mind, it still seemed a bit odd to Bill. She was still a teenage boy at heart, and she still wasn't entirely comfortable referring to herself as her current identity. At least in private, anyway.

Sure, in front of Ursula, her drop dead gorgeous wife, who was currently on Ganymede on a shopping trip, Bill played the role of Willow Strasserman effortlessly. Ditto for Willow's many, many new friends in this reality, not to mention the hundreds of thousands of people who worked for her. Bill still had trouble believing that her new persona had created an animation empire to rival Walt Disney, but the immaculate penthouse she lived in with the breathtaking view of Saturn, the constant vacations around the burgeoning stellar empire that humanity was carving out for itself, and the seemingly unlimited cash flow were reminders that, yes, this was very real. In front of employees and acquaintances, she was Willow Strasserman, genius, trillionaire, philanthropist, businesswoman, artist, futurist, and icon.

But that wasn't who she felt she was.

In her mind's eye, she was still Bill Elias Strasserman. She was still that geeky kid from Shermer, Illinois who loved Star Wars and Marvel and Rick & Morty, who listened to Bruce Springsteen when everyone else his age thought Born To Run was old people rock, who maintained an extensive gaming collection in the basement, who solved differential equations for fun.

She worried that she was going to wake up from this dream life one day and find herself back on Robinson Avenue. Back on Earth. Back in the 21st century, waiting for Rob Bolstrum to jump him and Matt Harris on their way to school. Or maybe his mother Martha Strasserman would come outside and yell at him for not feeding the cats that morning. Or maybe his sister Kimberly would try her best to irritate Bill in her vapid, tweenage way. The Bill portion of her brain was still waiting for her first date, her first kiss, her first prom.

The Grellstone had taken all of that away from her. The magic gemstone, shaped like a teardrop, had ferried her from the comfort of her life in 2015 into the far future of the 24th century.

She felt so irresponsible for not having tried harder to escape back to her original time period. She felt like she had abandoned her real family and her real friends. And yet...she was happier here.

Besides the beautiful wife and all the money and fame, it was a paradise for a geek like Bill, who had loved imagining what the future held in store. She remembered wanting to grow up to work for NASA as a little kid, but had been discouraged from it early on once she realized how much work went into it. Now she lived in outer space, and life in the 24th century, thankfully, did not disappoint in the Star Trekesque technology department.

For instance, the brunette beauty which Bill now was perpetually appeared to be about thirty years old. In reality, Willow Strasserman was actually 355 years old, having been born a few years shy of the turn of the third millennium.

Thanks to the miraculous nanobots swimming around her body, she was effectively immortal. Ageless. The microscopic robots which she had elected to become part of her were constantly maintaining and repairing her cells, tissue, DNA and more, keeping Willow's ancient flesh in tip top shape and preventing her from withering into a mummified husk.

When Bill had learned about that, she had been simply stunned into disbelief. And Ursula had undergone the same treatment!

Willow didn't dare tell Ursula who she used to be, or who she used to be. Once upon a time, several iterations of reality show, Ursula had been Matt Harris, his (male) best friend and star of the school's football team. The two of them, along with Matt's bitchy girlfriend Gloria Xanthopoulos, had accidentally used the stone to become triplet sisters, and through an improbable series of subsequent wishes, Bill had become Gloria's mom, Matt/Ursula's teenage girlfriend, and finally, after wishing to be far away from Shermer, Ursula's wife.

She pondered.. Should she risk pulling out the Grellstone? The magical artifact had transformed itself into a pretty necklace. Ursula believed that she had bought it for Willow as an anniversary present, and she often wore it out in public on special occasions.

Maybe she could use it somehow to bridge the gap. Maybe visit her original timeline. Maybe bring her parents and Kimmy and Matt to the the 24th century so they could live in splendor.

There were drugs out now that could trick the body into believing that it was angry when you actually weren't. Maybe if she popped one right now, she could fool the Grellstone enough where you could make a controlled wish.

You see, that was the trick with the Grellstone. It could alter reality, but only when you were furious and not thinking clearly. Bill had been too scared up until now to test the limits of the Grellstone, to see if it could be manipulated, but now she felt ready.

Before Bill could make a decision however, a green portal opened in the middle of her kitchen. Verdant light she immediately recognized spit out a boy of about eighteen years old, landing him on his spotless kitchen floor.

He coughed for a minutes, and then stood up and introduced himself.

"Hi...I'm Bill."

choices: “Gloria can’t bother me or Tom again!”
114122112112223333333131123.content:
Bill scratched the faint beginnings of peach fuzz on his cheek and sighed. The titles of these new realities were entirely too vague for him. Stepping into a new reality after he’d destroyed his own was literally the chance of a lifetime, but it wasn’t one he wanted to waste.

The Fairy sensed Bill’s apprehension, and gave a sigh of its own. “Is there a problem?” it asked with enough sarcasm to rival Gloria.

“I hate to ask—”

The Fairy interrupted him. “No you don’t.”

“Okay, no I don’t. But I do feel bad, and I feel kind of stupid for asking, but is there any way to specify the kind of reality I want?”

“You want a search bar?”

“Maybe? I don’t know. I’ve got no idea what I’d be searching for.”

The Fairy waved its hand over its wing, and a search bar appeared over the list of realities. Bill looked up at the Fairy, lost as to what to do with it.

“Okay kid, here’s how this is gonna work: you give me a description of the reality you want, and I’ll punch it in for you. You still get to pick the reality you want to live in, and try not to ask for anything too specific. Sound good? Good.”

“No, yeah, good,” Bill said, entirely aware that his answer didn’t matter. Even if the Fairy had given him unfair terms, it’s not like he was in a position to deny them.

The young man studied the search bar for a few moments while he debated what specifications he wanted to make. He tapped his foot, and the Fairy yawned, and finally he opened his mouth and said, “I want a reality where...”
114122112112223333333131123.title: A Beggar and a Chooser

choices: Bill picks a mother Ahn’Ger Stone reality
1141221121122233333331311231.content:
“I want a reality where Tom, Gloria, and I are happy!”

The Fairy snapped its fingers, and the words appeared in the search bar. Another snap, and a brand new list of realities showed up for Bill to choose from. He looked from the Fairy’s wings up to its bored face.

“So these realities have happy versions of the three of us?”

“No, they have versions of you that are happy. There’s a multiverse of difference there.”

Bill took a second to think over the grammar, then shrugged it off. He leaned in to the Fairy’s wing, and saw the list of realities waiting for him.

Cheer Squad

Married with Children

Beach Party Babes

A Horse is a Horse

It’s All Geek to Me


Bill blinked a couple of times, still unused to the concept of titles for realities. He’d read comics with different universes in them, but none were advertised as puns or pop culture references. Bill scratched his head, and accidentally caught the Fairy’s eye.

“You all set kid, or do you want more time?”

“No, I’m okay,” Bill blatantly lied. He leaned back into the wing, and prepared to choose his fate.
1141221121122233333331311231.title: Happy Days

choices: Picked one of the more fleshed out realities.
Picked one of the still beginning realities.
1141221121122233333331312.content:
After scrolling through several different screens depicting various different realities in which the Ahn'Ger Stone was present, Bill sighed. He couldn't do it. He couldn't face his friends and family knowing that he'd accidentally murdered them and left most of them to burn into ash in a fire caused by the sudden apocalypse. No, Bill knew that the only real choice was to go someplace else, to start over in a new world. And who knew, maybe he'd end up better off over there anyway?

"Can you just show me the different realities not related to the Stone?" Bill asked the fairy, who gave him a tiny thumbs up and flapped it's wings once, causing all the 'screens' within it's wings to change.

Bill immediately recognized a couple of them. Once again, the two guys in some house in what looked like California, messing around with a bunch of tools. And almost predictably, both of them became changed by the tools, resulting in several awkward encounters that...for some reason, left Bill grinning.

"Yeah that one is fun" The fairy said, looking over it's shoulder at that particular screen, "It's fairly lighthearted and goofy. It kind of reminds me of Dumb and Dumber, in a way. Oh and the sister of the more idiotic character is such a stoner. Like yeesh, talk about stereotypes am I right?"

"Um...sure?" Bill said, unsure of what else to say. He looked to another screen, the one with two families preparing for vacation. One family looked pretty unhappy, there seemed to be a lot of waterworks and yet nothing happened as a teenager and her younger brother were left at home while to adults left for a trip to Vegas.

"That one gets a little convoluted. Lot of different realities for that one" The fairy said with a shuffle of it's wings and all the screens became different viewpoints of that said world. "Basically you have the 'main' reality, which is Wilma and Fred Flintstone" The fairy pointed the husband and wife that clearly were trying to repair their marriage, "Getting into a fight and there's wishes, transformation, lot of crying, etc. With Betty and Barney here..." The fairy pointed to the other adult couple in a different screen, "Basically the wife goes a little mad with power and tortures her husband. It's fun."

"Fun!?" Bill said, watching the brunette command her husband around like a dog, using his money while the husband seemed like he just wanted to disappear with the other man and go fishing. "How can you call that fun?"

"Uh, because it is? I mean if you haven't noticed, kid, a lot of these stories torture the shit out of the characters. I mean even you, you're the guy that had infinite power in his hands, yet the only time you actually got to use the Ahn'Ger Stone was to wipe out all life. Doesn't seem like fun when you're living it, does it? But watching? That's a entirely different can of worms"

What the fairy said made sense. Despite the nightmare Bill was currently trapped in, he was honestly having a bit of fun watching the various universes play out. But there were other things to explore before he got caught up in another introspective spiral. "What about the kids in that story?" Bill asked, looking at the fairy's other wing where the screens seemed focused on the kids of the first adult couple.

"Oh, they get into the typical hijinks. Kids with magic, I suppose you know how that goes" The fairy grinned at Bill, and the teenager's face with hot with embarassment and anger. "But no, they actually get all mixed up at one point and even the Magic itself gets stuck in the situation. Might go places, though again I have no idea how you'd fit into any of these. Most of this particular story never made it past the first twenty minutes. Brand new worlds, lot of potential."

Bill pondered it for a moment and then shook his head, "No, not yet. Can we go back, please"

"What am I, Alexa? Do you want me to play Despacito for you while you browse?"

"Rude"

"Kid, I'm a five inch tall magical construct with wings the size of buses, trapped in a car with a dirty, smelly teenager in the middle of night on a planet where everything is dead. I'm allowed to be whatever I want to be" The fairy rolled it's eyes and leaned back as best it could while keeping the wings upright and visible for Bill. Strasserman couldn't really argue with the logic and wasn't about to look a gift horse in the mouth when it came to escaping his colossal mistake.

So instead he went back to browsing. The next big reality seemed to be pretty grounded. Another bunch of teenagers just out of high school enjoying a bonfire with friends in the state of Cascadia. then a dare and two boys wandered off into the northern woods until reaching the spot they had to stay at until morning. A not un-attractive punk chick up there waiting for them. And then nightmare creatures springing out of the forest, changing one of the boys into a woman while the punk chick and another boy managed to escape.

"The Wackerknobs. You know originally it wasn't supposed to be that, well, serious. But it really came together into a bit of a cohesive reality. The magic there even has rules it has to play by, which to me is just crazy. But yeah, apparently there was a huge plan for it but blame the editor." The fairy pointed a finger towards the roof of the car "Interest was lost. But yeah, maybe injecting yourself there could work to make it interesting again?"

"Well, what else is there?" Bill said, feeling the same dis-interest in that particular world. Maybe if he couldn't find anything else, it looked normal enough that it could be his back-up home just in case.

"Let's see..." the fairy mumbled and flexed it's wings, different realities popping up in the 'screens'. Many of them were simply blank, worlds that had yet to fully take shape. There was one that was about some kind of Magic Pen, a weird morphing app. One that had someone getting a head massage when suddenly they were in a some kind of high school romance manga. The The one that looked like Fallout seemed interesting, but Bill had already lived through the apocalypse that he had caused, and he wasn't sure if he wanted to live through another one. One that had time travel...one about some crazy tropical resort that had transformations....

Bill realized something "Hey" he asked the fairy, who was picking something out of it's crystalline fingernails, "Why are all these stories focused on transformation? There can't just be a normal world where nothing happens and life goes on as normal?"

"Because that's boring, kid. And these are the 'clean' realities. There's more out there that I'm not allowed to give you access to that are just, well, fucking gross, if I'm being honest. Handful of good ones, but most of them are just disgusting. It's better to stay in this general grouping of Multiverses if you don't want to be grossed out. And if I could give you access, well, that'd be on you, and I'm pretty sure you'd regret it"

"Wow"

"Yeah. Anyway, you gonna pick something? I do have other places to be" The fairy yawned and stretched it's tiny crystal limbs.

"Well, this one that seems focused on holidays seems neat"

"Yeah. Editor wants to get it up and running but the words aren't falling into place the way they need to be. Got a very 'Nightmare Before Christmas' vibe about it, though. Originally it was supposed to be all about monsters and getting trapped in mirrors, but the plan changed to be more light hearted."

"And the casino one?"

"Another one the boss wants to get going but is stuck on. Could be fun, up in the Big Green, rolling dice and gambling away your body! Though fair warning, the Editor did sort of have plans for that one to go dark. Not as dark as this nonsense you made, but more of a 'seedy criminal underworld' kind of dark"

"What's this one about a Remote and some guy named Mark? Bill asked, pointing towards another reality where a some slacker of a guy had found a remote with a hologram woman in it, and subsequently transformed himself into a almost disgustingly busty Asian woman.

"Oh, yeah. Forgot about Mark. Basically a screw up gets the tech version of god powers and inevitably screws things up for himself even further attempting to stall the apocalypse. He hasn't made it very far in his current reality, but elsewhere..." The fairy shook it's wings to the right and left as other images of Mark came into being. One of Mark becoming a woman for life, getting married to a senator, another trapped as a cheerleading outfit and then...as lipstick? Or ending up stuck as a teenager working at McDonald's before losing the Remote forever. Another trapped at a wedding as a flower girl, or even as his fiancee's mom. Even one screen that showed him as an almost racist depiction of a large, mad black woman on her way to work.

"That guy doesn't seem very lucky" Bill said as he watched Mark bumble through various adventures.

"Yeah, in other, older realities, Mark was a bit of an idiot. But that sort of seems the case for a lot of these. I mean hell, you make some pretty stupid moves yourself elsewhere. And, well, here"

"Hey!"

"I'm just calling them as I see them, kid. Now you gonna pick something?"

Bill leaned back in the driver seat of the car and thought about it for a moment before he...

Bill sat back and continued to swipe through the available realities, most of them remaining pretty blank.
1141221121122233333331312.title: Taking a risk and leaping into someone else'...

1141221121122233333333.content:
No one knew that the Stone was damaged. No one knew that no matter what Bill wished, it was going to do crazy, unpredictable changes to reality on a scale that it had truly yet to inflict. That was when Bill made his wish and the Ahn'Ger Stone flashed with light, blinding everyone in the Strasserman home and morphing the entire world around them. There was no telling what it would do, no tiny little prompts in the back of Bill's mind playing like a projector, no god figure on high pulling the strings of their newest little puppet in the Multiverse. There was no telling what would happen.

No, there was just the Stone, badly damaged, and the raging, raw fire of emotion that fueled the magic, pulled from places unknown.

As Bill squeezed his fist tight around the Stone, so hard that the curved edges bit deep into his flesh and causing a small river of blood to ruin the upstairs hallway carpet, he made his wish.

"I wish..."

Option 1: "I wish that you, that you'd...ARGH!" Bill screams in rage, unable to think of something terrible to wish upon Gloria. Due to Bill saying I wish, however, the Stone's magical energy is still released, washing over Gloria but also the rest of the world. When the dust settled, Bill finds Gloria standing where she was, her mouth open as a endless, bloodcurdling scream pours from it.
